review_body: At my boss' insistence, we relocated from the Shinagawa Prince to the Grand Prince Takanawa partway through our week-long trip. She had asked her admin to book this hotel from the start, but her admin had gotten confused. It's understandable: there are 3 hotels that are named pretty much the same thing within a 5 mile radius. If you've never been, it can be difficult to muddle through.Anyway, check-in was quick and easy, with everyone from the door staff to the front desk welcoming us in with smiles. Check-in was a breeze, and before we knew it, we were being escorted to our floor and to our rooms.I don't know what I'd expected, but the room wasn't it. Not that it was bad - far from it - but my boss made it sound like this hotel was the THING, and that we just had to stay there. Again, I had no complaints. The shower was mold-free (and had blessedly strong water pressure), the bed was comfortable and clean, and I had a nice view overlooking the grounds (shared with the other Shinagawa hotel across the way).I got better quality sleep here than I did at the other hotel, though that could also be attributed to my body adjusting to the 16 hour time difference.I did hang out in the club chairs early in the morning, while I FaceTimed with my husband back at home, or worked with the San Diego team before they called it a day.If you stay here, and the weather permits, definitely get out and explore their grounds. Like I said, there's a path between this hotel and their sister one across the way (which I think is also connected to a convention center). There's a large Koi pond, a bell and some structures that look old and probably had a good sign explaining their presence or importance that I totally missed.

We stayed in Grand Price Takanawa from 11/21 to 11/19/19. The hotel is beautiful, the garden is wonderful, the service first class. But it does not have a convenient store near by or machine that sell us sundry, soda .... for that we have to walk to the 7-11 in Grand Prince Shin Tankanawa (a 8-10 minutes walk but not much fun when it is dark at night and we have to walk through the dark garden path), There is also no microwave available anywhere in the hotel. The hotel do offer 24 hours room service that would run about $40-60 for a meal and several restaurants in the property that cost between $60-120 a meal each person. The only problem is that we paid about $176+tax a night for our room and we are not ready to spend that much money in it’s restaurants. It is middle to upper middle in term of price range for Tokyo hotels but the restaurants are design for clients that spends 5 star money. if you don’t want to spend that much money on a meal, the location of the hotel become a problem, It is on a hill that is about 10-15 minutes walking from Shinagawa station (depending on how fast/slow when you climb the hill walking to the hotel). The hill is between 10-15% grade, walking is not exactly a good solution after a long day of sightseeing. There is a shuttle bus every 20 minutes between the hotel and Shinagawa hotel. The problem is that it serves 3 Prince hotels (Tanagawa, Shin Tanagawa, Sukura Tower). In our 8 days stay, we had 2 occasions that the shuttle bus was too full (only 24 seats) and we were left at Shinagawa station trying to figure out how to go back to the hotel, In one occasion, we took a taxi back to the hotel (about 600 yen’s or $5.5). In the other occasion, we had to walk at night because the taxi line was exceedingly long. I can’t help but think that shuttle bus prole will much more serve in Summer time. Picking Prince hotel Tanagawa is a two edge sword. The room is big (225 sq ft or so), service is great, bell person / front desk spoke very good English, hotel ground is beautiful. Airport bus stop at the airport. The downside is that if you need anything, you need to go to stores around Shinagawa station. Walking up and down the hill is not fun nor practical for travelers new to Japan if the shuttle bus is full. Using taxi at some point should be part of the plan. Hotel restaurants are meant for clients with much more expensive taste (and they already booked Grand Price Shin Tanagawa) than what the hotel is currently charging their rooms, so travelers like us has to figure out their dinner plan ahead. I am very happy with our stay at the hotel. But we will probably book Shinagawa Prince hotel given it’s better location and proximity to more restaurants and shop within walking distance.

The standout for us was the helpfulness and friendliness of the Hotel lobby and front of house staff. We did not dine in so can't comment about the offerings other than the room. The room was very spacious, comfortable and well appointed. We previously stayed at Prince Hotel Sakura Tce next door and this feels like an older version of that (older but still clean and tidy).Overall for price and location I would have rated it excellent except one major fault which was a big let down and I assume (hope?) is only temporary - the room temp was set at 25C and we prefer a colder room - only after payment and check in when we rang to ask why the aircon did not seem to be working were we told - "not working, don't use it, open a window". Not a practical solution unfortunately on this particular date and after a bit of discussion we were provided with cooling unit for the room which tried hard to work but did not really do the job. So staff did well to try and sort this for us, but something as significant as this should have been advised to us before we accepted the room / checked in.

Nice hotel, helpful and friendly staff especially in the lobby. Lovely garden out the back.However as mentioned above we stayed here on 3 occasions for the RWC. We found the price of food and drinks in the hotel restaurants extremely expensive, not sure if that was a RWC ripoff or what.Also the breakfast buffet was a disaster, they couldn’t cope with the crowds, kept running out of bread, teabags and other items. The toaster was a huge bottleneck.The omelettes were never cooked.We are returning to Japan next year but will not be staying at the hotel.

Located just 5 minutes away from the local train Station, the Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa is a modern well appointed hotel. The room was quite large with a good sized bathroom. The Slope Side Diner offered a really good buffet breakfast.

the hotel was billed as 4 star I would suggest it just makes the grade here. That being said its a great hotel that suited what we wanted which was abase for the RWC 2019 trip. The Breakfasts were very good in the buffet not so in the ala-catre the rest of the food I am not sure as we were out and about.The non smoking rooms were great in fact excellent if a little old the smoking room (when requested non smoking) were disgusting the smell of smoke and the stale smell were horrible but seeing it was RWC finals you take what you can get.The in hotel laundry was great but expensive and the 7/11 downstairs was very convenientwalking distance to the train station and some good eating spots soalll in all worth the price

Booked this hotel for my business trip. It is near Shinagawa station Takanawa exit. The room is big and quiet. It is clean but abit old. 2 things I like: there is a small japanese garden in the middle of the Prince hotels which the guests can go for a walk and the hotel provides free shuttle bus service to Shinagawa station

We arrived by train and since I’ve stayed here before it was easy to find. The check in was swift and we quickly came to the room. The room was fairly clean and everything in the room and bathroom was functional. We had some problems to work out how the lightning worked. Outside there is a wonderful Japanese Garden and despite the heat, we spent an hour in the garden.

This is the smaller of the three properties with a similar name. So be careful. Has a beautiful garden that is accessible all day. It’s 5 minute walk from Shingawa train station with access to all trains include the bullet trains. Rooms are small but that’s normal for Japan. Has modern room amenities. Quiet and low key property with very good service. If you’re looking for more luxury, i.e. grand lobby, restaurants, etc try the sister property. But everything is shared between them.

Hotel reception is a beautiful area, big hotel But room is plain & stuffy. Air-con is not cool and the air-purifier machine does not help either. Bed is hard, pillow too soft. Average stay for me. Location is up-hill, and takes about less than 10 mins to train station.

We stayed 2 nights at this hotel and liked it a lot. It was quiet and the view on he garden was really worth it.The room was not huge but ok for japanese standard. The bed was large and comfortable. The bathroom was small but very efficient, looked like all the bathrooms I saw in Japan, some in plastic and others, like this one, in some kind of stone..... marble ?The restaurant in front of the garden was excellent and the staff very helpful, at night with the sherry blossoms illuminated it was magic !!!!I highly recommend it

Two nights stay work related. Arrived at 6am in the morning, and stored the luggage to check in at 3 pm. The rooms on the club floor fully refurbished with all the amenities, to get started we had Ala carte breakfast at the restaurant was quick & fast.The buffet breakfast choice is unbelievable for the next two days was fantastic at the Side Diner Zakuro. The Prince hotels in one block and most beautiful gardens surrounding the hotel including fish ponds, and the most beautifully decorated lobby with very high ceilings and a great place to stay not to mentioned the service is spot on. Close to the Shinagawa station a few minutes walk down to the station, Aqua park and the restaurants around the area 25 Minutes to the apt or by train.

Location is very good, 650 mts from Shinagawa Station and the Shinkansen. There is a shuttle running from and to the station if you don’t want to walk up a small hill. The hotel is one of a cluster of three big hotels surrounded by beautiful gardens, a big bonus. Rooms are OK in size. Furniture is outdated and in some cases in need of some maintenance. Service is professional. Beatifully decorated lobby as one expects from a 4* hotel. Shuttle to Haneda and Narita airports available at a competitive price. Recommended.

So, if you stay there, ensure you choose a deluxe room and business lounge access for the extra dollars.The hotel has a great location with beautiful gardens. However we booked executive floor, received the lounge access but a small 14 Sm closet to stay for three nights.Moved into a much larger room when we became part of a Rugby World Cup group for the remaining four nights. The food options are very limited. The hotel is tired. But the staff are excellent.

We stayed at this hotel for 7 nights, three nights in a small room, and then four nights in a bigger room. The small room was squashy, but the bigger room (king size bed) was very comfortable. The hotel is located in Shinagawa- a busy suburb with an excellent train service. The train is close by. The hotel is set in the grounds of 3 other hotels (all Prince hotels) and all hotels’ facilities are available to each guest. So lots to choose from. Shinagawa also has many restaurants and bars. The best part was the serene garden setting - an oasis compared to other hotels which front a busy street.

Great syndicate of 3 hotels around beautiful gardens. 4 or 5 excellent restaurants to choose from and wonderful staff. Feels better as the days go on.Right near the main shingawa train station so easy to get around from here.

This was the first hotel for our Japan tour organised by the JTB and it was excellent. It’s one of three interconnected hotels and while the New Takanawa is very impressive, we were delighted with the service, our room and the provided breakfasts. The room was spacious, quiet and well appointed. We had been unable to purchase Aus/Jpn adaptors with two flat pins before leaving Australia and the young man that so helpfully brought our luggage to our room and showed us around also went and got us an adaptor we could use. The hotel restaurants take last riders around 9-9:30 each night and with our late arrival on day 1 we thought we might miss out, but the snacks cafe and bar had a reasonable selection of meals and we were able to eat after arrival. From then on the hotel is so well located in relation to Shinagawa Station and its wonderful range of restaurants that we ate away each night with a nice, warm (and occasionally wet) walk each way via the adjacent New Hotel Takanawa.

Super Hotel in Tokyo ! Room was excellent with manycomplimentary amenities (bottled water every day-freecoffee/machine in room). There is a free shuttle bus every 20 minutes to theShinagawa Train Station-where you can catch trains andmetro to most places. Train Station is on the Main Street-is about a 5-10 minute walk down the hill(remember u have to walk back UP it if you don’t waitfor the shuttle). Wide variety of shops and restaurants. Train to Ginza about 20 minutes and very easy to follow routings-Shibuya about 15 minutes. Check-in staff very helpful and courteous!Even had bellhop who refused tip for carrying 2 large suitcases. Overall a great hotel with a lovely garden to stroll around in.

We were a party of 3 adults and 4 kids, two family with kids ranging from 15 to 5. We had two rooms and per our request after our booking via booking.com, the hotel allocated us rooms next to each other. I’m Japanese married to an Aussie so we often visit Tokyo and this time his brother and his teenage kids came too. Anyhow, we had the triple room. My kids are 9 & 5 so can have them sleep on one bed. Shinagawa is my go to for accommodation because it has direct access to airports and bullet trains along with smaller scale station that I can navigate easily with kids in tow alone or in a large group. It also has kid friendly places like the arcade, aquarium, bowling alley and karaoke boxes along with lots of restaurants to choose from and supermarkets and food court. There is even a row of ramen shops and Kula revolving sushi. There are 4 Prince hotels in Shinagawa and all of them are nice. We just choose the cheapest with best room on offer. This time it was the Grand Prince Takanawa. It’s up the hill, above Sakura Tower but below Grand Prince Shin-Takanawa. The 3 hotels share a Japanese garden with koi pond, a bell and temple. After a long day in chaotic Tokyo, the garden’s tranquility is peaceful and also entertaining space for kids. We love the hotel and will always go back if we can. As my kids grow bigger though, I may not be able to since I think the biggest room they offer is a triple. I could be wrong (I’m hoping). Anyone looking for a nice, comfortable hotel to relax in, this is a great option!

There are a cluster of hotels near a busy train station. This picture does not represent the beautiful building I stayed in which had lovely gardens and walks. There are many "Prince Hotels" and properties. I would recommend the Grand Prince New Takanawa which is in this same cluster of hotels.

Good hotel with fresh cleaning everyday by the housekeeping team. Great work. Walking distance by 10 min to the station, but they Have a shuttle bus Every 20 min.The room was a bit old, could get updated.Restaurant prices was a bit overpriced.A big thank to Mr Mamoru Iwanaga at the reception for great hospitality after a long flight. Also the rest of the team were great!

Like an oasis in the crowds of central Tokyo, the “Grand Prince Taganawa” is very centrallylocated to catch the Shinkansen or the express train to Narita Airport at the Shinagawa station.by max. 10 minutes walking. Very friendly personnel, as always in Japan, and clean, nice rooms.Good buffet breakfast, though only white, soft bread.We did not have lunch nor dinner at the hotel, or at the other sister hotels nearby since we foundthe prices far too high.

Simple rooms which are clean. Becoming a little e bit dated. Small bathroom. Bed was comfortable. View is not very special. No safe in room. Energy savings means room is a little warm during summer. Location is not ideal as there is a walk to local restaurants and train station. Best part is the beautiful gardens. Front desk staff really nice.

Grand Prince hotel Takanawa is a good hotel just 5 minutes’ walk from Shinagawa station. You can also get there directly with a shuttle bus available every 20 minutes, during the day, which makes the route between Narita airport and most of the hotels in Shinagawa. The staff is very kind and helpful with the customer, its English is fluent and waiting times for check in and check out are perfect. You can choose among various types of rooms, and the size, cleanliness and furnishings depend heavily on what you choose. I booked a Deluxe King room, and found myself in a room large enough for two people, comfortable and well cleaned. The room temperature was easily managed by a digital thermostat, in the wardrobe there was an iron and the bathroom was equipped with a bathtub, not a shower. The hotel is surrounded by a beautiful Japanese garden, where you can walk and relax. You can eat in the hotel but also around Shinagawa station there are several places where you can have lunch or dinner. I only had breakfast in this hotel. Western breakfast is barely adequate, not up to that offered by the nearby hotel Sakura. There is no machine for cappuccinos or coffee and table service is not offered (at least I could not find it). Drinks are kept to a minimum but bread, croissants, some yoghurts and a couple of types of fruit are available. However, it is a good place to stay for business or tourism.

For the business part of my trip (AKA company paying) I was booked into this hotel, the location is up a hill, so the view is stunning. They provide a shuttle bus from Shinagawa station every 20 minutes from 8am to 9:20pm. The gardens surrounding the hotel are very peaceful, a place for a lovely walk. The rooms are spacious and the bathroom has delightfully fragrant toiletries. The bed has a better mattress than I have at home. The breakfast, well, what can I say?? Even if you are a picky eater, you will find something. They have omelets cooked to order, fruit, pastries etc.

This has always been our favourite Tokyo hotel. Mainly due to the great Japanese gardens , which attracts continual Japanese weddings, and the breakfast room looking our over this garden.However this time our booked room was not ready and we were offered a Japanese room in a little building off to one side of the entrance. Didn't know it existed. The room was 100 sq meters with Japanese style soaking bath, reed mats, western beds, great electrics, paper sliding room dividers, dining area and so on. unique experience. Better than ryokan. Slept three with roll up mattress for our child but could have slept more.Anyway there's the secret. We'll book same on our next visit.

+ : Friendly staff, great location, nice connection to 2 other hotels (Sakura and New Prince Takanawa)- : rooms need major updates, dated already, more seats in the lobby, better buffet breakfast menu

Night Of Stars Celebration Nu Skin Starry Starry Night Celebration Of Success In Tokyo & Success Stories ☺️We celebrate all success trip winners and enjoy the ambience and success stories of others with Nu Skin event.

This hotel is strategically located and they have magnificent huge and beautiful garden which full of sakura trees and huge koi pond. Really beautiful and you can explore and get little adventure on their garden which connected to other hotel ‘new’ but I haven’t try it out. Room is a bit small but cozy.

Although I had never used this hotel, stayed because other hotels were fully booked. In spite of check-in at 14:00, I had been kept waiting for 40mins. They had never apologised, and behaving like it is normal.In addition, the room image is totally different from photos in the website... I cannot believe it is superior! It’s too small.今で一度も使ったことのないホテルですが、他のホテルが予約で埋まっていたので、今回初めて泊まりました。2時からのチェックイン。これまでどこのホテルでも、2時チェックインの場合、2時に部屋に入れたのでそういう意味だと思っていましたが、なんと部屋の準備がという理由で４０分も待たされました。それが普通と言わんばかりの態度…加えて、スーペリアって…えっこれが？と疑問を抱くほどウェブで見た部屋のイメージとは異なりすぎ。何より…狭すぎ。

The Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa in Tokyo is perfectionist in every detail. I. Room , amenities, even deepest bath tub ever ( in the Japanese style rooms ) , convenience, club lounge and ofcourse luxury in food as well as services .The Japanese style rooms are spacious , and the area around the hotel offers 20,000 me of parks ( which is rare in Tokyo ). Special regards to Azusa Suzuki who , despite being a very typical rules and regulations Japanese, managed to blend to the special needs of demanding travellers. TV channels are in Japanese.
