review_body: We stayed for a week and found the hotel very convenient, being a five minute stroll from Shinigawa Station (or there is the free shuttle bus); from there we could access pretty much anywhere in Tokyo. The station complex also contains a department store, large grocery store, tiny international grocery store, coffee shop, and much more. The hotel staff were unfailingly courteous and helpful. I cannot name the scent in the lobby, but it was fresh and inviting. The decor is very brown, but the room was larger than I expected, clean, and gave us a wonderful view of the delightful Japanese garden and koi pond in the middle of the hotel complex. I would definitely stay here again if the opportunity arises.

Stay in this hotel a few times. Like the location, near the train station with lots of eats nearby. Room are big enough and clean. There is a 7-11 in the hotel and it is well stocked. Toilet size is a bit on the small side.

Slightly pricy lobby bar. Very friendly staff. Excellent breakfast. Gym is small, mainly running mats and indoor cycles. Room was old fashioned but did its job for overnight trip. Location fairly near to the railway station.

If you want to move back to the 80´s that is the place to go. The room design is really horrible truly old fashioned but well maintained. The preferred color scheme in the room is brown the same applies to bathroom tiles.Breakfast is really bad the choices for western as well as for Japanese food are really limited. The really good thing about this hotel is the location. It couldn’t be better right in the heart of the city next to Shinagawa station.

I like this hotel as the rooms are of a decent size for my family of 2 adults and 3 kids. The hotel has been refurbished since I last stayed here 10 years ago but the rooms look a bit tired and are probably due for another renewal soon. I used the free shuttle to and from Shinagawa station a lot and the TaQbin counter at the lobby was very convenient. My family enjoyed the short stroll to Shinagawa through the Japanese garden in the mornings.

The Grand Prince Takanawa was a great hotel with superb accessibility to the station. It is about a 4 minute walk to the station. People travelling with bags should note that it is a slight uphill walk to reach the hotel. We had priority lounge access all throughout the day with the room category we had reserved. This facility was very convenient with coffee, drinks and snacks available all day long. They open at 7am which gets you an amazing compact breakfast before you leave for sightseeing or business. The rooms are quite small, families travelling with kids must note they will need bigger suite category rooms or interconnecting rooms. Views from the rooms were great, cleanliness was up to the mark and staff was friendly and accommodative. The hotel is connected with its sister concern hotels and has great gardens and grounds.

Nice and big hotel situated close to the Shinagawa train station. It even has a shuttle bus, free of charge, from the hotel to the station.You have the possibility to have your breakfast in several locations and the continental breakfast was excellent. Big variety of fresh and tasty products.Room was spacious and mine had an nice view on the Tokyo skyline. Staff was very friendly and spoke English well.Overall a nice experience.

I can safely say the service at this hotel was one of the best I've ever had and the room/price very much in line with my expectations. Everything was clean, organized and smooth.My girlfriend also are particularly grateful to Tomoaki Harada; in an incident where one of our charger was damaged by the house keeping service, he immediately stepped up to find a solution to our charger need and reimburse in full the damaged item.Lastly, I'd like to thank Junya Ishida who so kindly helped us make reservations in advance, to both a restaurant and a museum, while we were still out of the country.

I came from Tokyo but work aboard, therefore each year we will return to Tokyo for family visiting & shopping retreat. I know many foreigners think the room is small, but in Tokyo i think this hotel got pretty big size room compare to many many others. Here is my opinion;-Good about this hotel : 1) Services are superb, outstanding staffs2) Room is pretty good size in Tokyo with what you pay for3) Hotel is super clear and even the towel is super white , means they are good in quality control even they are a very popular hotel choice 4) the Garden is so lovely and so Japan. You wont find similar in other hotels5) they do have limousine bus to either Narita & Haneda airport (Haneda only 3 time slots only per day, so be careful) 6) 6 Mints to the Shinagawa Station and got seven- eleven on B1 the hotel next door. Things could be better or need to be improved : 1) Gym is extremely small and only have running machine & bike. It is not real gym... so you need go to next door hotel to use, but it will cost you JPY3,000++ even you are the guest in the same group hotel. 2) Breakfast choice is limited and no Gluten-free and with out 2 days stay , the food is the same every morning3) baby chair is not normal baby chair, no seat belt, for family with young kids , be prepared, it will be so hard to keep they stay still. So far we are quite happy with this hotel and hope hotel GM can read the message and other add some weight training equipment in the Gym or not charge guest to go group hotel gym because you don't have it yourself & Gluten Free option for guest is necessary i think, Most 5 star hotels offers gluten free option for people got Gluten allergic. If wasn't the gym , i'd give the hotel 5 rating out of 5. Still a good hotel to choose from many others.

The Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa is located about a 10 minute walk from the Shinagawa train station, the hotel also has a bus service that picks up at the hotel and drops that the train station which makes accessing the hotel convenient. I was very disappointed by the room that I received. I booked a "renovated" room on Expedia and paid extra for this. The room I received was NOT renovated, the furniture was old, the carpet was dirty and the walls were stained. The bathroom as old and outdated. I asked the hotel for a different room and they advised they were sold out.After I left the hotel, I contacted Expedia regarding the misrepresentation. Expedia called the hotel, the hotel said all of their rooms are renovated. If all of the rooms are renovated, why did Expedia have an option to pay more for a renovated room? After complaining to Expedia they refunded my room. The hotel itself is in a great location, lots of restaurants within walking distance of the hotel. The hotel sits on very beautiful grounds, really nice to walk around.

This hotel is located off a side-street to the West of Daiichi-Keihin (Route 15) just North of Shinagawa Railway Station.There are 3 large hotels in a cluster around a pretty Japanese Garden, all owned by the same Hotel Group:• Prince Sakura Tower Hotel Tokyo (East side)• Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa (North side)• Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa (South Side)It is easy to get confused with the names, as they are similar. There is also the Shinagawa Prince Hotel nearby.The Grand Prince Hotel does have its own small barrier-controlled carpark for which an extra charge is made. The Railway Station is only 5-10 minutes’ walk away, up the hill past the Sakura Tower Hotel.The Reception and the Rooms are very spacious. The Rooms are clean but a little dated in decor. It is possible to open the windows and air conditioning is also available, as is Free WiFi. Drinks from the Minibar are charged and will not be automatically topped up when consumed.There is a Breakfast Room serving a good selection of food and drinks, a Lounge serving lighter meals and a formal French Restaurant which is not always open. Also a Smoking Bar in the basement which is well stocked with Single Malt Whiskies.Meals, including breakfast, can also be taken in the other nearby Group Hotel Restaurants.All the Staff are polite and friendly.

We stayed here for almost one week. Very nice hotel with big rooms and nice view from the rooms. The Japanese garden was a nice feature in the middle of the city. It is difficult to find a so nice place to stay in Tokyo.Breakfast is very nice.

I spend 10 nights in this hotel and here is my review:The region: It is located in the Shinagawa region, which is a quite, non-touristic region.The train station is 5min walking and if you take the green train line, you can go immediately to all the central regions of Tokyo( shinjuku, Harajuku, etc) in maximum 20min. There is also an amazing sushi restaurant in the neighbourhood called ”sushiryorinosi” that definitely worhts a visit! ATTENTION!If you are coming from Narita airport there is a bus that goes directly to the hotel called Limusine Bus. Don't take a taxi, it is super expensive.The hotel: The hotel has a beautiful but not obercrowed reception and the staff are always willing to help, most of them speak English well enough. It has an amazing Japanese garden in the back yard and a good tepanyaki restaurant. There is a swimming pool, but you have to pay to visit, and a very small, basic gym for free.The room: It is very comfortable and big for the Japanese standards. People say that the decoration is outdated, but when you come back from a long day around Tokyo, you really don't care if the walls are painted beige, or the bathroom has old-fashioned tiles, you care for a comfortable bed and a clean bathroom, which you get. The cleaning service is excellent and they include plenty of amenities like combs, tooth brushes and women's amenities. The room also includes teabags and we thought they were for free, but they charge it almost 4euros for one teabag!But anyway in Tokyo you have to be prepared to spend a lot of money.If you don't want a hotel in the more central ereas, I would definitely recommend this one.

I had been told Japan is expensive but the hotel surprised me.We arrive morning and it was just after 11 when we arrived at hotel. To be told we could check in now but we had to pay part day as check in was 2 pm.It was not cheap but we were tired so paid,The rooms large and well equipped. Staff very helpful. We headed to the pool, which is actually with next door hotel Grand Prince Hotel new Takanawa, when we arrived at pool we. Were a bit concerned as it’s not large and not many loungers, but when queues for towels I was shocked to be told we had to PAY to use the pool.3000 yen each, this was an advertised feature of the hotel and I choose hotel as had pool, was far from impressed this amount of money for what was a pretty basic pool area. Would not come here again!

The hotel is close to Shinagawa station, about 7-10 minutes walk away. There is a shuttle bus that runs every 20 minutes. It does get crowded but worthwhile getting back from the station especially in the heat and humidity of summer as it is uphill.The hotel reception areas are nicely presented and modern. The staff are excellent and everybody was more than willing to help. English wasn't a problem for most of them. The rooms are OK size but a bit dated. Too much wood veneer and I haven't seen a bath with a shower curtain for years! They are very clean though. There are a couple of downsides: 1) The restaurants are very, very expensive - four soft drinks Yen5,000, Breakfast for three Yen11,000 2) There is a charge of Yen3,000 per person for using the swimming pool. The pool is in the other hotel and is unspectacular. There are actually two pools, Garden Pool and Sky Pool. The Garden Pool is adults only. The Sky pool is very shallow. I think it stated 0.6m. Note - The hotel is one of three in the same location. We didn't go into the Prince Sakura but did go into the Grand Prince NEW Takenawa (where the pool is) and despite the word NEW in the name it definitely seems older and more run down than the Grand Prince Takenawa

It's our second time to stay at Taganawa Prince Hotel in Tokyo. And stil we would like to come again. The room we have stayed was at the fift floor facing the japanise garden inside the area of the hotel. What a lovely view wethear its in summer or at spring time , each season with wonderfull blossoming.The inside hotel is decorated with wonderfull japanise style. The room is very spacious and well equipped. The restaurant in breakfast time was very tasty and rich including japanise and westeren food. Nearby, 5 minutes wallking is the Shinagawa railway station.

Right across the train station! We took the train everywhere so this place was perfect stop. The rooms were spacious and had a great garden view! This hotel is one of 3 joined together by a magnificent Japanese garden. Right across a major shopping area and lots of places to eat.

The room was quite big and the common areas were very zen and nice. Breakfast area is also very nice, with great choice. The garden is beautiful and so peaceful, a joy to walk in any time of the day. It is almost unbelievable that, only going up a short hill, this hotel offers such a calm atmosphere in Shinagawa. There are various Prince hotels in Shinagawa, only some meters from each other. We were coming from the huge Prince Shinagawa (old, crowded and tiny rooms) which is not nice and this Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa seemed like heaven!

Stayed here for three nights. Chose it as it was close to the Shinagawa train station which has direct rail service to/from Tokyo Haneda as well as most of the subway liness and has a Shinkansen stop as well.Very nice spacious room overlooking the garden shared with other Prince hotels. There are three or four "Prince" hotels near the station, one of which is a New Takanawa so be sure which one you are going to.there is a shuttle from the Shinagawa station to three of the hotels which runs every 15-20 minutes or so and is recommended if you are bringing bags, as there is a small hill to climb if you want to walk. Not insurmountable, but not something you want to drag bags up.Staff were very helpful and courteous. We only ate breakfast at the hotel once and while the buffet was nice it seemed pricy $72 for two. We found a great breakfast place down by the train station - Pronto - that was only about $5USD for an omelet, toast and coffee.Would definitely stay here again.

I stayed here for 5 days and overall, I had a great stay. The staff were always willing to assist you, and most of them speaks English. The rooms and the hotel interior were bit old, but it still maintains its classy look.There is also a garden at the back of the Hotel where you can roam around.Will definitely stay here again.

Hi dear travellers!!Our team had a stay for 2 weeks at Grand Prince Hotel,and we enjoyed our staying there.A relaxing music at the lobby,everything with nice japanesse style,friendly staff....all of this creates a pleasant atmosphere!!Beyond the hotel is a nice garden and a lake with friendly fishes),so in the evening you enjoy the garden and forget about city rowdiness...Shinagawa station is 5 minutes walking from the hotel,close to it are enough supermarkets,restaurants and any shops...Breakfast is arious,delicious and you have a big choice..Also for the environment,if you don't need cleaning,you complete a paper,and in the evening you receive a coupon for 500 yen,and you may use it at:restaurants,massage,laundry or local Seven-Eleven!!!So i recommend you Grand Prince Hotel!!

We stayed here on business in 2017. The staff spoke excellent English, and we had no trouble at all with languages trying to communicate with my broken Japanese. This hotel shares a garden with two other Prince Hotels in the same area, and the grounds are simply stunning. I enjoyed the koi ponds, the waterfalls, the moments of just communing with nature in the middle of the city, and the aroma of the foliage. It was very refreshing to walk around in the morning and just before bedtime. I suggest the shuttle from the Shinagawa station to the top of the hill, unless you really like to work out your leg muscles climbing up and down the very steep hill.

Stayed here to a total of 6 nights on a business trip and always had good service. I left my laptop bag in the airport limo and the staff very quickly got in touch with the limo company and got my laptop bag sent back to me within 24 hours. Amazing! Breakfast spread was very nice, plenty of selections. They have a nice Japanese tea garden in the grounds and a large koi fish pond. The location is very near the Shinagawa train station and they have a shuttle that takes you there from the hotel every 20 mins. If you prefer walking, it would take you around 10 mins from the hotel to the train station. There is a 7-eleven nearby too which was very convenient. The bed in the room was very comfortable. Room was clean, Wifi was also very smooth. I would stay here again.

My 3rd and last stay as I have to be in Shinagawa I thought I give it a go againThe room smells like a nursing home eher only 90 plus people liveIt terrible thank god only 3 bights and I am out and never ever back againMind you, I stay up to 240 days a year in hotels all over Asia for 18 years!!I guess, I know how a hotel should be for a business traveller, beside I was living 1,5 years in TokyoThe Prince hotels need caucasian management and a replacement of the local staff or a slave driver who gets them up to speedThe location is great to access the trains!The breakfast is way and I mean way overpriced!!The sauna you have to pay as a hotel guestBetter go outside it's cheaper and betterFor the poolThey ask you JPY 3'000.00No shade no umbrellas Where in the world. Do you get a service like this??Japan !All you want - you pay!!Japanese never care about customers everOnly in the front of the Medaille all looks friendlyThe trues is, customer service does not really has a value the Prince group only care about the money, so this hotel too Good advise check the map for better option

Large spacious lobby area, nice large comfortable room in a quiet area away from the bustle around the station. Large counter in the room for working with your computer along with a settee for comfortable sitting. Up the street from Shinagawa station, about a 10-minute walk. There is a 7-Eleven in the building – hours are from 7:00 a.m. to 1:00 a.m. They have a shuttle which takes you down to the Shinagawa train station. It goes 8:15 a.m. thru 9:15 p.m., running every 20-minutes. I took the 10:15 one and it was maxed out with the pull-down extra seats in the aisle all occupied.

This hotel is located excellent near the Shinagawa Station. It is rather traditional Japanese hotel with very friendly and helpful staff. Rooms have a good space with the necessarily amenities. The bathroom is somewhat outdated with a bath as shower.

Solid hotel in a very good strategic location near shinagawa station; you can get to different areas / locations in the city easily.The garden is beautiful - a little oasis in a crowded big city.The lobby / bar is modern and spacious - but the rooms are quite old-fashioned and outworn.

Picked Shinagawa for our first night in Japan as the it’s close to Shinagawa Station and catching the shinkansens makes logistically easy.Professional and courteous staff welcomed us on arrival.We were upgraded to their king size room for the one night we were there. And the room was massive, 4 seperate rooms, king size bed and very spacious bathroom. A rarity to have in Japan.While the furnishings are a little dated, it was a very comfortable stay.Breakfast buffet was plentiful in options and the lovely garden outside is well kept and plenty of Koi fish to check out (plus the off turtle or two).Thanks again and we hope to come back again (even if the upgrade doesn’t happen :) )

If you need to stay in the Shinagawa area then their are a few different hotels to choose from. The four different prince hotels are very close to the train station and are affordable if you book in advance.

Let me say first that I really wanted to like this hotel. I stayed at one of the other Prince hotels, the Park tower, around 10 years ago and had an absolutely fabulous day I genuinely couldn’t fault a thing and it’s one of my only five-star reviews on TripAdvisor.To be fair, the price at this hotel was very good compared to other hotels of a similar star rating in Tokyo so perhaps I’m being picky. However this is my second night and quite a lot of things have niggled me so far.The room: I paid for a club room and as such I expect a decent standard of room. The room is small and the bathroom is absolutely tiny if not claustrophobic. I know that Tokyo hotel rooms are small but again I stayed at the park tower a few years ago and the club room there was enormous. The bathroom here has a shower over the bath but it does not even have a fixed showerhead on the wall.The room itself is not too bad but for some unknown reason they have positioned a chair and a tiny table in the room which makes it impossible to walk to the bed. It is very clear that the room is far too small for this additional chair and table and basically it just stands in the middle of a gangway to the side of the bed. It’s just very silly and points out to everyone quite how small the room actually is.Breakfast: The reason I paid for a club lounge was to have access to a simple breakfast and evening drinks perhaps. Big problem is that coffee at breakfast is absolutely undrinkable. There is a coffee machine but as you look closely you will realise it is a Nescafe instant coffee machine and has never seen a fresh coffee bean in its life. I have just come from a Doubletree hotel in China and the coffee machine there served me beautiful expresses every morning. I even asked for filter coffee to see whether it was available in the club lounge but basically no; what you see is what you get and there were no other options available. I’m sorry but something resembling good coffee in the morning is absolutely necessary of a good class of hotel.Club lounge drinks: this evening I was out with my local agent having dinner and returned to the hotel at 8:50 PM. The club lounge is advertised as serving “nightcap drinks” until 9 PM. Therefore at 8:55 PM I poured myself a glass of wine in the club lounge only to be told at 9 PM that the club lounge is shut & asked to leave. Everyone knows that it does take a while to drink a drink after it has been poured therefore what on earth is the point of shutting the lounge immediately after the drinks are removed. I have never been in this situation before as normally a club lounge is open for at least half an hour after the last drinks or food is served.Opening hours: following the above “get myself a drink” disaster, I tried to retire to the bar only to be told that last orders were at 9:30 PM. Now I consider this very early for a full service hotel but no problem, had a drink and then left at around 945. At this point I saw another number of guests coming into the bar, who had just arrived from a flight and were clearly agitated that at that time they could not get a coffee, a drink or any food whatsoever. I don’t really understand who this hotel is aimed at. It clearly is not international business travellers or holidaymakers as presumably all these people have requirements outside the hours of 8am-9pm which appears to be the opening hours of the hotel.Overall, genuinely disappointed and certainly would not stay here again or recommend to others. I am also confused as it’s not in any way like the Prince Park Tower where I stayed many years ago and had excellent service all round. This hotel needs looking at and the market for it needs to be understood correctly as at the moment they are not serving anyone particularly well.

This hotel is well situated between either a JR station (Shinagawa) or a Metro station (Takanawadai) which is why we decided to book here.The hotel room itself is reasonable size for a double room in Tokyo as majority of them we browsed online seemed quite small. One negative point is the room itself seemed quite worn and dated. I’m sure the New Takanawa hotel next to it would have been more contemporary and newer.Another issue experienced though was the safety deposit box in the room was not working properly. However this was swiftly resolved by a call downstairs and they sent someone up to check and eventually replaced it.We received standard amenities such as shower gels and other toiletries and this was replaced after each day when the room was tidied.We also had a decent view as the room allocated was at the front so we could see Tokyo tower in the distance which was nice.I wasn’t aware of the shuttle service between the hotel and Shinagawa station until we left as the lady porter at the entrance informed that it was free between the hotel and station and runs approximately every 10 minutes.Overall a nice but dated hotel, however reasonably priced for Tokyo. I would like to try the new takanawa hotel next door to compare the rooms but would equally recommend and wouldn’t mind staying here again.

The Grand Prince is a very spacious hotel which exudes tranquillity and comfort. All the staff were cheerful, friendly and very helpful without being intrusive. Our comfortable room (1253) was well equipped and had views across the beautiful gardens and lake.The club lounge offered a wide range of cuisine for breakfast and a welcoming atmosphere when we popped in for the occasional coffee or evening drink. The hotel restaurants we found a bit pricey but a good quality meal at a reasonable price was available in the bar lounge area. A five minute walk from Shinagawa station meant that we were ideally located to benefit from the many attractions offered by Tokyo. We enjoyed in particular the Sky Tree Tower. The Grand Prince Hotel played a very important part in making our two week stay in Tokyo very enjoyable.

Wife was here on business and I was staying for vacation. Super convenient to shanigawa train station that will take you anywhere you want to go. Rooms are nice, lobby is nice and casual. Most of the on site eateries are decent. The employees all were terrific. Neighborhood is not much for tourism but there are lots of interesting temples. Very satisfied with stay here.

The room was reasonable with all the things you need, not to far from Shinagawa station; near restaurants and a very lovely park with fish and various seasonal flowers. I am sure you will like it very much.

Tokyo is a busy, sometimes very crowded city so the Grand Prince Takanawa was like our sanctuary after long days of seeing all Tokyo has to offer. Large spacious room - with two beds together was a large king, chairs for relaxing, and well supplied bathroom amenities. North American power outlets and they supplied a multi charger for electronics. We had a garden view of the beautiful Japanese garden and enjoyed walking in and through it everyday.Easy walk to Shinagawa Station and the hotel operates a shuttle - handy when you’re arriving with luggage. The Airport Limo bus also stops here and tickets can be charged to your room.

Our first experience of Japan in the height of the Cherry Blossom period set a high standard for the rest of our holiday, Our room, which was larger than we expected, overlooked the delightful gardens with superb advanced cherry blossom trees surrounding a pretty pond with large lazy koi.it was about a half kilometre easy walk down to the Shingawa station again under a canopy of white blush tipped blossoms, but the return journey was uphill and it is better to take advantage of the free hotel shuttle bus which runs about every 20 minutes. There are lots of well priced cafes round the station - meals at the hotel were expensive! There are also a few supermarkets too - we especially liked the Wing one downstairs on the right hand side facing the station..Breakfast at the hotel was a plentiful buffet - lots of choice and dishes in either western style or Japanese - but it was around $40 per head.Staff were very efficient and friendly - all in all a greaat start to our holiday.

The room was 75 degrees every day and cooled only slightly 1-2 degrees overnight. Apparently they don’t have AC on the cusp season like April, meaning don’t book here. Not much you can do to cool down. The hotel is older but manageable apart from that.

This is my 2nd stay at this hotel and more than 5 times that I also stayed at Prince Sakura Tower and Grand Prince NEW Takanawa Hotel. The benefit of Grand Prince Takanawa among the other 2 is the price! The location itself is equally convenient since all of them are sharing the same compound. One thing that you need to take note is there is some room that still not renovated so please request or book for renovated room. However, the room itself, I would rate Prince Sakura Tower as the best room but Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa is also acceptable. Another thing that I like this hotel is the lobby is not so crowded or busy unlike Grand Prince NEW Takanawa which there is always a lot of tour group and crowded. The breakfast buffet is nice. There is also nothing to complain about the service.In summary, if you got the budget, just go for Prince Sakura Tower. If budget is a bit concerned then I would recommend Grand Prince Takanawa.

It was a really nice and convenient hotel but there is no air conditioning when the weather is cold so we had to sleep with the window open which wasn't ideal. The location of the hotel made up for it but the staff don't know even the basic of English so it wasn't ideal either.

My wife and I spent 8 nights at the Grand Prince in a 14th floor Superior King Club Room. I would offer a very strong recommendation. First, the hotel is located 1/3 a mile from the train station up a moderate grade hill. Shinagawa is a major station servicing many train lines including the high speed bullet trains. The hotel offers a shuttle between the train station which loops every twenty minutes early morning to night but is shared with two other Prince hotels. There were times when too many people wanted to board the shuttle and were turned away. The walk to the hotel from the station isn't bad although negotiating the hill with luggage or dealing with rainy conditions makes the shuttle quite desirable. The hotel was the oldest of the four Prince Hotels in Shinagawa, but was recently renovated. The room was quite spacious by Japan standards, although the bathroom a bit small compared to luxury US rooms. A desk area, floor table with two chairs, US power plugs, and digital TV with many American channels made us feel right at home.The grounds of the hotel are quite nice with a beautiful courtyard / park setting framed by cherry blossom trees. The club room was excellent - breakfast was quite hearty offering both American (fruits, pastries, bacon, sausage, omelette station, yogurt, etc...) and Japanese (miso soup, fish, rice) daily. The room has nonalcoholic beverages and fancy coffee drinks all day, at 5 pm to 9 pm alcohol is served with various appetizers / desserts. Pricing out Shinagawa hotel rooms with included restaurant breakfasts with a club room at the Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa during our March travel window made the decision pretty easy for the club room. Having experienced 8 days at the hotel and the great complementary breakfasts made me quite happy with the decision. I would add though, our room 1459 was immediately adjacent to the elevated and you could hear it whoosh by regularly.

This is a nice hotel but please ask for the new block with the Japanese rooms - this is nice and the air con works here. If you are on a congress in the area the hotel is okay. The breakfast is okay, I just miss my full corn bread.

Nice hotel, but do not cater for long haul clients, 32 hours to arrive and jet lagged, 4 am came down for a coffee or something - NO SERVICE! Only room service, hotels need to offer alternatives, it’s a long way and would be +, we don’t want to be stuck in rooms

This hotel is a cluster in three hotels. The hotel is large with large rooms from Tokyo standard. Good bits... Location 200 metres away from shinagawa station with malls casino and restaurants nearby. Room sizes are large and reasonably appointed. It's an old hotel so don't expect cutting edge design in rooms. Hotel has a large swimming pool and garden and a free shuttle to the station. The hotel also has a seven eleven in its basement and a TGI Friday, outback steakhouse, Mcdonald, cafe and bar nearby.The rooms are nice and clean. I my drawback is the bathroom. It's quite small and cramped with no seperate shower place. The basin is also set quite low and even though I had a twin room that bathroom was pretty small. The room has a nice balcony but nothing great in terms of views.Overall a great location and nice large rooms right in the heart of town

Stayed for 3 nights had a comfortable stay. Every room has a balcony which is actually very nice. Breakfast is not too elaborate but reasonable choices. Staff is courteous and helpful. Had made a room service order which was quick and fast.

You could be forgiven believing the Prince Hotel Group owns the whole of Shinagawa. With 5 Hotels surrounding beautiful Japanese Gardens it can be confusing which one you are staying in. There is "Prince", "Grand Prince", "Grand Prince New" as well as "Hotel Sakura" & "Goos". The good news if you check into the wrong one they happily transfer your bags! The staff are very helpful & there is convenient Hotel shuttle bus from the nearby railway station servicing all the Prince Hotels approx every 15-20 minutes.Rooms are comfortable & good size as well as well appointed bathrooms. (not capsule). With easy access to JR line it is ideal place to choose as Tokyo base. Range of restaurants nearby & good bottleshop that will pull the cork for you if you have forgotten to pack the opener!Range of activities nearby including indoor aqua park & bowling

My wife and I just spent 4 nights at this fine hotel (not to be confused with the Shinagawa Prince Hotel, the Prince Sakura or the Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa all in the same neighborhood). I will start with the service - simply great. Always ready to help and answer all our inquiries and take care of our needs. I want to specially mention Junya Ishida and Yuka Wakii who went out of their way to help us with three lost bags that did not arrive with us from our flight with AF from Paris.The room was spacious with a comfortable bed and pillow. Bathroom although not modern is functional with strong hot water in the shower.Breakfast room is lovely with a very impressive buffet selection. The cook remembered our order for 4 minute soft boiled eggs from the first morning and had it ready for us on consecutive mornings. Quick check in, a 5 second check out. Attention to detail - that is the story of this hotel.And located just 7 minutes by foot (go through Japanese garden) from Shinagawa Station (from there you can go anywhere in Tokyo and way beyond).So yes, we would highly recommend this hotel.

The breakfast was amazing, kept me going all day.I especially love the toilets with the music and all the cool features, but i think that this is standard all over Japan. Gardens and music room are absolutely breathtaking.Don't wear your pjs to go for breakfast, this isn't your typical go slow lazy vibe beach front chilled hotel. Rules are enforced strictly and the culture is conservative.The rooms are modern and comfortable. One of my favourite hotels :)

The decor of this hotel is more pleasant than its sister hotel 'New Prince' nearby. The rooms are very pleasant, but the breakfast buffet is disappointing.The highlight of the hotel is the garden behind, which is an oasis of tranquility, and is especially beautiful in the autumn.

We stayed at the GP Takanawa (not the New Takanawa) on 11/10 thru 11/12.The service at this hotel is excellent! Check-in friendly and efficient. The shuttle drivers were also very concerned about our safety as we boarded and departed the bus as there were tons of taxis passing thru shuttle pickup area. During our stay the staff always greeted us when we were on the lobby. They wished us a good day when we left for sightseeing and welcomed us back when we returned The room itself was very nice and comfortable. Perhaps the best testimony to this hotel is that we chose to return on 11/21 thru 11/26. At 11/19 I️ still could have chosen to cancel our reservations and make other arrangements (we’ve done this before at other hotels)I️ However we were more than happy to return to this hotel. GP Takanawa is on the top of our list when we visit Japan again. Dont forget to visit the lovely garden in the back of the hotel if you do decide to stay there

Nearby JR station in Shinagawa area, walking distance to mall and eatery places. Hotel breakfast buffet has quite good spread of varieties but typically the same for every morning. Hotel has a beautiful garden with a pond that linked with the Grand Prince New Takanawa hotel. The garden view from my room is wonderful especially during the autumn season. Overall room is comfortable.

Located just around the corner from Shinagawa station it is very easy to get around from the hotel - there is even a shuttle that runs every 20min to the station for free, but it’s just as easy and nice to walk there. They also have hourly shuttles (for a fee) going to both Haneda and Narita airport (although for Haneda it is just as easy to catch the train). The room was fairly small and the hotel is quite pricey, but then that seems to be the standard in Tokyo. The room was comfortable and with the expected amenities.

I arrived late at the train station returning from Kyoto and I did not pay attention to the notice of a free shuttle to this beautiful hotel. as a result I walked up to the new GRAND PRINCE HOTEL TAKANAWA. It is without a doubt even more beautiful . The front desk staff were very helpful and walked me to my hotel which by comparison was old elegance vs new and beautiful and sleek . The gal that checked me in was helpful and gave good advice regarding how to take the train to and from the Kappabachi area. She even gave me printouts of the station guides. not much was open at night in the hotel. The room was small, clean and okay. I hd been at the Tobou hotel levant and they provided water and at this hotel you had to pay for everything. even the mustard pretzels they had out . I didnt mind paying but I would have liked to know what was complementary. The shuttle was helpful to the station. but I did not ask about the return shuttle when I came back to collect my bags to get to the cruise port at Yokohama.I walked back, it was easier in the daylight.Getting to the port was easy with the directions the hotel provided. did I get value for money? not 100% convinced that the pricey rate was waranted.

We stayed at the Grand Prince Hotel for three nights during the Cherry Blossom season. The garden outside the hotel during Cherry Blossom was blooming and very beautiful. The location was close to the Shinagawa Train Station which is very convenient. The staff at the hotel was very good and attentive.

Stayed here four nights. Nice rooms, beds are hard and in Autumn they switch to the heating system so no air con available. Window opens a little so was ok at night. Room didn't cool if there was no breeze. This hotel is on a complex with two others and there are eight or so restaurants across the three.call very expensive and fine dining, not recommended for flavour of Japan. There is a shuttle that rounds three times an hour to the station where there is a few restaurants to choose from. I actually went to 7/11 which is in the basement of the new hotel. The bread sandwiches are very fresh and last for days, ended up having those for breakfast. Very cheap.Staff very friendly and helpful although I would probably stay closer to normal restaurants and the station.

Maybe we were having unusually warm weather for November so the cooling system was not working, but the room we had was too hot. If we slept with the window open it would have been too noisy so we endured the muggy room instead. The manager kindly offered us a fan and explained that the hotel is old and the air conditioning was really only used for heating.Location for us was fine. Shinagawa is a big hub station and access to and from the rest of Tokyo was good as well as Haneda. We wanted to be close to the airport so that we could catch an early morning flight without too much hassle. This suited us geographically perfectly.Must say at this point that the gardens are really lovely too and worth a stroll around. The rooms are also a good size with all the usual amenities that you would expect. Shame there was no access to any? many? English language channels for news on the television.

Just squeezes a 3 out of 5.Hotel is in a great location near to Shinagawa train station but nice and quiet spot. Lovely little Japanese garden around the hotel. Typical Japanese service, very helpful and polite staff. Pleanty of in house restaurants to choose from if you don't want to go out and breakfast menu has good variety.Downsides, fitness facilities really poor, just two treadmills and two bikes, it's not a gym. Swimming pool closed.No air-conditioning due to being autumn, however when the room is warm which it has been the only option is a noisy fan or open the window but then you can hear the road.

Hello everyone Seriously nothing mean against them but for sure you don’t want to stay here...Lobby is ok, direct access via Limousine Bus from Narita and a nice garden outside: that’s it!Of course they are helpful and polite like almost every where in Tokyo but beside thatCheck in is at 2 pm, room are overpriced very old ( really very old) and cheap furniture The hotel is quiet from outside as you are not on a street but in a backyard/ parking garden.Seems ok from outside but really pass your way.

Located 10 min walk from Shinagawa station but need to walk uphill for 5 min. Half hr by taxi from Haneda airport. Next to Wing shopping mall which has McDonalds and Shinagawa station has supermarket. Twin bed was comfortable, fridge, slippers, kettle provided. Breakfast was western and Japanese and delicious. Compound has a nice Japanese garden shared with New Takanawa which has a 7-11.

Situated at the heart of city , one needs to get down I stop beyond JR express while traveling from Narita at shingawa Be careful as the whole area is full of Grand Prince hotels I made mistake of mistaking Shingawa Grand Prince for Takanawa Grand prince & walked only to be told that I was about 5/10 minutes away to Grand Prince TakanawaRooms are cozy & nice , there is a small Gym as well

Hotel is a 5 min walk from Shinagawa station, but that is an uphill walk if you have luggage. The hotel has a shuttle that runs regularly during the day and taxis are plentiful. The rooms are comfortable, dated but on the large size for Japan. Staff were friendly and helpful. The Japanese garden out the back is gorgeous and you can walk through it down towards the station. We didn't eat in the hotel, there are too many food options nearby and the hotel restaurant prices seemed very expensive, welcome to Japan.

The hotel is conveniently located within 5min walking distance from Shinagawa station. The Japanese garden includes a large pond with big carps - dont miss out. Gym and garden is shared with Grand Prince New Takanawa hotel.Nice breakfast lounge.

Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa is quite more luxury comparing with Prince Hotel Shinagawa where I stay last month which is just across the street from Shinagawa JR station but the location of PHT is a bit further as you have walk pass other hotel across the garden so make this hotel more quiet and isolate. PHT is newer with bigger room. Also you still can use Airport Limousine bus to both Haneda and Narita which is very convenience.

We stayed here for 4 nights and it was just a hotel.There was no concierge available any of the days to ask for local information. The bar drinks were overpriced and the basic service was very average.The bathroom was small and old and rundown.I'm sure the grand prince new would be much better.Positives is it was close to train lots of eating places in walking distance.

Location: Great. Just on Shinagawa station. close by Tokyo, Oinachi and Shinjuku. Hotel: Rooms are okay. I have seen some of tiny rooms in Japan where one can barely stand in wash room. Very spacious rooms. Gym is just for name. They have two tread mills and two cycles, thats it. Approach to hotel is very strange. Its a long walk inside. You need to climb stairs, which goes difficult once you are reaching hotel for check in. Food is good. Charges reasonable. Wifi works okay, though some time late evening almost dead for some time.

Without Japanese language skills, I appreciated the English speaking ability of the staff and their genuine attempts to support my needs. My room was very good, albeit compact and the hotel does a good job in most areas. Areas I would like to see improve:* Room wireless connection - you needed to obtain a code through the TV and apply this to gain access. The wireless signal appeared strong but the connection rarely worked - too complicated and ineffective* "Fitness Room" - COME ON! This is tiny and only has four cardio items. I know space is at a premium in Japan but if the hotel can have multiple restaurants, a cigar shop and large foyers, it can do much better than a fitness room with no weights or cable machines - VERY POOR. This is just a lack of recognition of customer needs in the 21st century. * Breakfast - buffet is not up to International standards. Cutlery on the tables some days but not on others? A chef who will prepare boiled eggs but doesn't realise they need to be put in cold water after cooking so they are not too hot for the guest to pick them up? Papers available some days but not others? Espresso coffee from the machine is watery. The offering needs to be reviewed.

If you are travelling for business than make sure you pay a little extra and book a club room. The club lounge is a great place to have a business meeting and to enjoy breakfast and evening cocktails.

This hotel really shines for me. It's a quiet and beautiful hotel. (Very Japanese styled hotel ie. the facilities available etc) Yes, the rooms were a bit dated but the service, location, gorgeous gardens and pool make it worth it. If I hadn't booked else where I would have definitely extended my stay. I like the breakfast buffet although it's a bit expensive. The pool staff were very nice. Actually, all the staff were attentive. The change rooms remind me of a 1970's film. Definitely, there is a lot of people who attend for conferences so that part of the conference area can be hectic for some but it doesn't make the hotel noise. I was also happy with the bed too. It was firm yet comfortable. We stayed in the triple room. It was cosy but I can't complain as we overlooked the gardens. Also, should mention that we were here for leisure. There is an 7-eleven ATM in the 'new' Takanawa hotel that you can use. The lobby area of the 'new' Takanawa hotel is a lot more busy than this one.

Very Zen to stroll by its garden. I imagine it to be very pretty in autumn and spring. Walking and having tea in their courtyard feels like of a royalty. Hotel is at close proximity to Shinagawa station, with direct access to Haneda and Narita airports. Walking to the hotel and back to the station every day is not that bad, but could be a challenge for those who are not used to walking uphill. Those who don't wanna be hassled with walking may use of their free shuttle service.Rooms are spacious for Japan standards, with standard amenities: tub, toilet and bath, king-sized bed, tv (though I wish they provide English movie, sports and news channels).Would definitely consider staying again.

We spent one full week at Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa as it was close to Shinagawa station and gave easy access to all of Tokyo from here. The room is quite large by japanese standards, bed was extremely comfortable and the bathroom functional with good hot water and water pressure. The hotel is quite elegant and is very well maintained. Our room was always perfectly maintained by housekeeping ladies.Like a lot of hotels in North Asia the aircon/heating is controlled by the hotel so it take a little adjusting to sleeping in 24/25'c air, fortunately the hotel provides an excellent modern fan device which we finally worked out how to use and that made the air move around the room and keep it a little cooler.If you are a western traveler or from southern asia would not recommend taking the hotel breakfast everyday. We had it once and found it quite challenging for non-pork eaters. It is also very expensive. There are any number of supermarkets, coffee shops and cafes at Shinagawa station only a 7 minute stroll down the hill.A great feature of the hotel (which is in a cluster of four hotels) is the shuttle to the station and back, It runs every 20 minutes, although at times you may have to wait for two or three shuttles with the crowds going to the station with bags. If you walk do so.One final thing is the lovely japanese garden that sits between the four hotels. Very popular with weddings so if you are here on a Saturday get down there early with your camera for all the formal/kimono wedding groups.

Mind you, I stay up to 240 days a year in hotels all over Asia for 17 years!!I guess, I know how a hotel should be for a business traveller!!The location is great to access the trains!The breakfast is way and I mean way overpriced!!The sauna you have to pay as a hotel guestBetter go outside it's cheaper and betterFor the poolThey ask you JPY 3'000.00No shade no umbrellas Where in the world. Do you get a service like this??Japan !All you want - you pay!!Japanese never care about customers everOnly in the front of the Medaille all looks friendlyThe trues is they only care about the money, so this hotel too

This is one the prince hotels that are near to Shinagawa station. Although, you can walk to the hotel from the station, I wouldn't advise that and I would say just wait for the shuttle bus from Shinagawa to the hotel. If you are flying to Tokyo and will be staying in this hotel, I would advise you to take Haneda airport rather than Narita coz it will only take you around 30 mins to arrive to the hotel. Rooms are just fine. Nothing extraordinary but I like that they have a long desk near the bed where I can put my bags and laptop.

Everyone we interacted with at the hotel was extremely polite and helpful. The room was beautiful, spotless, and had everything you would need. The garden is beautiful and the walk from the station was fine. It's a great location near Shinagawa station on the Yamanote line and easy to get to most attractions around the city. We did not use the pool at all since we were busy around the city all day long so can't comment on that. But I would definitely stay there again.

Large clean hotel quite close to Shinagawa station. I had a long room and the bed certainly was a proper king and the room was of a standard international large size and was the largest room I stayed in while in Japan. Staff are very polite and the garden outside the hotel is nice. The "hill" mentioned in other reviews really isn't much of a hill. You have the ability to walk through the gardens of the other grand prince hotels in the same complex to skip the walk. I walked from the station to the hotel with two heavy bags in the middle of summer in 40 degrees celsius weather with about 60% humidity and it wasn't too bad. The reason for my stay was to stay someone close enough to HND airport on my last day in Japan. The hotel offers a coach transfer to HND international for approx 720 yen.

This hotel actually has king size beds which is amazing as every other hotel we stayed at in Japan ( 5 of them) did not! It is dated and needs a renovation badly! A bit disappointed that pool is only open between 10 am and 5 pm! If you do anything during the day, you can't use the pool! Bathrooms are a bit old but they provide great toiletries ! And the breakfast is very good except that they had cut the mangoes with the same knife they had cut the fish so all my fruit was wasted! Nice central location and very close to Shinagawa station; they also provide a shuttle bus if you don't feel like walking!

We fully enjoyed our stay at the Grand Prince! It is one of 3 hotels on a beautiful complex of Japanese gardens and peaceful pond of giant koi fish. Very Zen to see every morning and to stroll by. I'm the hotel is very close to Shinagawa station and a straight shot from Haneda airport - so convenient for a stay on Tokyo and very good value. We had no problem walking to the hotel and back to the station every day and thought the "hill", which is really just a small incline wasn't bad at all. Who couldn't use a little exercise after all the daily sushi and ramen? Lots of amazing ramen joints nearby also. Must check out "ramen alley" underneath the station. The room itself has everything you need and is a great size for Japan standards. There is a gym on the 2nd floor with a few cardio machines and ilwendid take advantage of the treadmills a few days over our stay. Gym room is very small so make sure you turn on the fan or you'll heat up fast! The best part of our stay was the exceptional service by the staff, from arrival, departure, the to shuttle service staff, everyone we interacted with questions, everyone was ready genuinely greet us and help. Just absolutely amazing service that supercedes most Luxury hotel or any other high end service experience I've had. What makes the staff at the Grand Prince stand out to me is the level of authenticity they convey in their interactions with clients to exceed expectations in their experiences. We loved our stay in Tokyo and plan to return. When we plan our next trip we will be staying at this great hotel!

Correct no breakfast included. But great comunication with Tokio. A seven eleven next door and good topical restaurants. Big queen size bed with lots of gadgets on the bathroom. They hay a refrigerator to put your own drinks

This is acrually a cpmplex of 3 different hotel.Typical Japanse hotel - clean, silent and with polite service.Hotel has a wide buffet breakfast, but it's bit expensive. Bit overpriced in my opinion.Basically everything is fine, but hotel located on hill, which means you have climb every time when you return from city.Nice thing is, that you can lso walk through japanese garden, which is very nice and relaxing.

Very enjoyable stay at Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa. The hotel staff are always courteous with a smile ready on their face. The hotel is not very fully booked in this season and it is very quiet. We loved the quietness and the zen atmosphere. The flowers arrangements is very mesmerising. The Japanese gardens outside of the hotel is with full bloom hydrangeas. The only negative point is the breakfast selections for the club lounge. They prepared very little quantities. One of the dishes is braised beef with carrots and potatoes (nikujaga) but we never ate any beef for a few mornings even though we were generally quite early at 8 -830am. We asked for beef refill for the dish but were told twice that they only cooked that quantities. The club lounge staff was very apologetic about it but this happened twice and it's apparent the hotel is on a cost cutting measures. My take is that if you are offering breakfast in club lounge as part of the whole package, then be generous about it. They had refills for steamed vegetables which was very lovely but not the beef. How can the dish be called nikujaga if its with potatoes and carrots only. My advice is to be generous about your portioning. Otherwise, it's a lovely place!

Location: The hotel is very close to the Shinagawa Station,which is easy to access to both airport in Tokyo. However, it is up in the hill. If you are trying to bring your luggage and walk to the hotel, it will be quite tough. I suggest to take a taxi even though it's short distance. A few Prince hotel in the same area, make sure you don't go to a wrong one. Room: Big room in Tokyo standard. The room is a bit old, but generally ok, with a air purifier + humidifier, iron and a small iron board. Bed and Pillow is comfortable. You can see Tokyo tower from one side of the hotel. The other side of the hotel has a nice Japanese garden.

This is a very nice hotel with rooms that are large by Tokyo standards. Our room was clean, and the beds were comfortable. We even had a view of Tokyo Tower. The hotel is conveniently located within a 10 minute walk from Shinagawa Station, which is one of two bullet train stops in Tokyo and is also served by several JR East train lines, the Narita Express from Narita International Airport, and the Keikyu Line from Haneda Airport. Although the hotel is close to the train station, it is an uphill walk from the station, so I recommend taking the free shuttle bus that runs between the station and several Prince hotels.

I love this hotel!! Even though it might be a bit tiring to carry your suitcases from Shinagawa Station uphill (I walked for almost 15 minutes with my suitcases), I still consider the location convenient. You could also wait for the shuttle bus provided by the hotel if you don't want to walk. Rooms are decent. The most amazing part is the Sakura garden within the hotel complex. It's actually very pleasant to just pass by during Sakura season.

Great location, just five minutes walking to Shinagawa station. Take JR Yamanote line for Tokyo, Shinjuku, Shibuya and other central locations . Travel time from Shinagawa station to Haneda airport takes about 22 minutes and the train goes approximately every 8 minutes (Look for Keikyu-Kuko Line). Hotel has a small Japanese garden. I've seen a couple of weddings here, so I assume it's popular for weddings. Around this garden there are also other Prince Hotels. So make sure you are not confusing it with Grand New Prince Hotel.

Th hotel is easily accessible. The staff were, as expected, polite and very helpful. The rooms are well appointed. The "american breakfast" was good but not sure the broccoli sprout added a great deal. The buffet cafe was excellent value. The highlight though is the Japanese Garden which is very peaceful and restful.

Nice hotel in very good location. The rooms are a good size, the bed very comfortable and the view fantastic. Staff are very helpful and breakfast buffet was good. A bonus is the shuttle bus to Shinagawa station.

This hotel is a great place to work while in Tokyo. A close walk to the train station you can get to it by express train from the airport. We were able to catch the train or cars to our meetings without problems. The rooms are spacious for the area and everything, food, service, was excellent.

Stayed at this hotel during a business trip. A note when booking said the rooms were newly renovated and that made me choose this hotel. For the renovation, sure enough the room was nicely decorated, you could tell the carpet an furniture was new and that was very pleasant. The renovation however did not extend to the bathroom which lowered my grading. In 70style brown decor, black spots between the tiles(mold?), poor lighting (putting on makeup was a bit hard), not enough room to put up your own amenities I was a bit disappointed. Minibar with very small selection. The TV offered a few international channels like BBC, CNN and Fox but at certain times they were dubbed in Japanese. Besides the room itself, the hotel is situated nicely with a small park outside. It is a nice place for a small stroll. The reception area was heavily perfumed, to that level that it becomes troublesome and this was the case for multiple days. Not just at one occasion. Did not utilize any restaurant or other facilities during this trip.

The rooms are large, by local standards and for the price. The bedding is wonderful, and the amenities entirely adequate (including a kettle that doubles as a thermos dispenser). The room - and the hotel overall - were quiet, and staff unobtrusive. There's pleasing greenery around the hotel, though far less than there once was, and a pond with monstrously large carp. The proximity to Shinagawa Station is brilliant - walkable within 10 minutes, if you've only got hand luggage/roll-on - but be aware that the hotel's on a modest hill, which could be strenuous for some. Shinagawa is easier to navigate than Tokyo Station, and a breeze for the bullet train and Narita Express. Wander through it to the east side of the station to find a rabbit warren of small bars/eateries/izakaya hopping every night of the week. To the south of the station and poorly signposted, one flight up in an office building, Kura Zushi takes conveyor-belt sushi to another level and is full of Japanese families.The Takanawa Prince opened more than 50 years ago, in time for the 1964 Tokyo Olympics. While you're there, read Lesley Downer's excellent book, The Brothers, on the hotel's owners, the Tsutsumi family, whose patriarch was the Trump of that era.

We 38 persons are residing in this hotel since 22nd March 2017. As we reached after a journey of more than 36 hours we found our room keys ready . Room was very well made. I had once previously visited Japan. Am very impressed by the people of Japan . Staff very cooperative and mannered.

The staff here is friendly and wonderfully helpful.Our room was quite large by Japanese standards. The bed was big and comfortable, with all non-feather pillows. Each nightstand had a power outlet--perfect for charging phones and devices at bedside! The room had a mini-fridge, coffeemaker, electric tea kettle, iron, ironing board, and hair dryer. The two free bottles of spring water were a welcome sight. All hotels should provide this!The bathroom had a shower/tub combo that had smelly, unsightly mold in the tile corners that needs to be scrubbed thoroughly by housekeeping. The water pressure was good and the hot water stayed hot. The wash cloths were nice and thick. The towels were rather thin but they were very absorbent. The toilet paper was very thin and lacking.The hotel has several restaurants and lounges, and is located very close to numerous restaurants, bars, and shops. There are two other Prince hotels connected to the Grand Prince by a lovely Japanese garden. Breakfast was abundant. The free WiFi was strong.Despite the hotel's very few shortcomings, the room was nice and the location is good. I would consider staying here again the next time I'm in the area.

this is first for me to visit japan, i went with my family and my little daughter.i love this hotel, warm and friendly staff, always help us to inform us about transport, food and many attractions place.they also have great park behind the hotel.and thank you for free shuttle to station, the driver always help us for that

Stayed in deluxe king room for business trip. Room is spacious with amenities provided. Nice ambience with a pond and park around the hotel. Going to train station requires a walk down the slope. Will consider staying again

Nice business hotel with a very pretty Japanese garden enclosed by this and the other local hotels. The room I had was a good sized western style room that had been fairly recently updated. Very comfortable bed and very clean.

Having been newly renovated, the Grand Prince Takanawa does show a new and shining face. The lobby is cozy and has a calm ambience, like most Japanese style of low-profile beauty. Location:Located about 10 minutes walk from JR Shinagawa Station, the hotel is not extremely convenient especially when you are taking kids and holding luggage. However, it's embarrassing to get on a taxi because the distance is too close when you go by a vehicle. The hotel provides shuttle bus service to/from JR Shinagawa Station too.Room:The room is relatively small but having a view of Tokyo Tower in front of me makes me no further complaint. It's clean and has all amenities you need.Club Lounge:This is by far the best part of the stay. The Club Lounge is brand new, with ceiling-to-floor glasses overseeing the big beautiful Japanese garden. The cocktail time is surely the best time to visit. Different kinds of snacks and alcohols are available, with a quiet environment. But, note that kids are not allowed to enter the Club Lounge after 5pm. This makes most family vacationers difficult because you cannot leave your kids in the hotel room, right? So, perhaps the parents need to go by turn, if they really want to enjoy the cocktail hours. The natural sunlight makes breakfast time there very refreshing. They offer Japanese style breakfast and international style. Varieties are good enough at any standard. Staff service quality is at top level.Price:Very reasonable, compared with what is offered. I highly recommend it.

Stayed at Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa for the first time. It was recommended by a friend and was told the place is newly renovated. Indeed the room is new, clean and well designed. Staff are professional and accommodating. Very impress with their enthusiasm and willingness to go beyond the call of duty to accommodate my family without fuss. Wile the hotel is 10 min walk to the nearest train station, the hotel provide a shuttle bus service to Shinagawa train station every 20 minutes and it is very convenient.Behind the hotel, there is a beautiful garden. A morning stroll in the garden is very relaxing and calming. Will recommend friends to stay here at Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa.

The hotel went through a major upgrade and re-opened in early November. According to the hotel staff, the most important purpose of this upgrade was seismological, but it also brought in new carpets, furniture, etc. It definitely looked much cleaner than before.

I stayed here for a business trip and was thoroughly impressed with the amount of space I had - especially for a hotel room in Tokyo.The beds are very comfy and the bathroom is very clean and again, very spacious for this part of the world.All the toiletries you need are provided (all sealed and packed new): comb, hair brush, toothbrush, toothpaste, hair clips, cotton wipes, needle, threads, shampoo, conditioner and body lotion. If you forget to pack something, their supplies will last you until you get a chance to pop in to a convenience store.There is a convenience store about 5 minutes walk away if you would like anything extra for your room or last minute supplies.The hotel was also able to store luggage for me for a week as I travelled to Kyoto and Hiroshima.Staff are exceptionally polite, very professional and pleasant, and very willing to help.I didn't eat at the hotel, however, my colleagues advised me that there was both western and Japanese style food that was very fresh and delicious.There are also many restaurants and eateries located around the hotel.Just on another note that might be helpful for visitors: during my entire stay, everyone that was in the lobby / around the hotel were immaculately dressed, i.e. no thongs / slippers and shorts to go down for breakfast.The hotel provides a free loan of umbrellas - very handy if you go for a walk through their stunning garden and it starts to drizzle!There is a smokers room at the front of the hotel if you are that way inclined - it was nice to be undercover and not stuck in the rain! (serve's me right for being a smoker, right?) It is well away form everyone and has 2 doors to enter so nothing smells like smoke until you go in the actual room and light up.A lovely hotel with lovely, helpful staff.The only thing I could point out that was strange - I asked for an iron and ironing board when I arrived and staff told me that they only had one for the entire hotel and that it wasn't available. I politely asked again and made a point of stating that one iron for a hotel of their size was ridiculous and asked very kindly if I could have the iron when it was available.5 minutes later, staff emerged with an iron and ironing board.As I went up to my room, I noticed another iron and ironing board leaning against someone else's door. Clearly, there is more than one iron available in the hotel.I know - it might seem trivial in the grand scheme of things, however, I refused to meet with colleagues for conferences in a chewed-up state. Even more so in Japan, where everyone places so much pride and effort in their appearance.So my only advice here would be if you need to be tidy and pressed, insist that you please have access to an iron.I would happily stay here again on a return visit.Japan is a marvellous place with the loveliest people in the world!

This hotels location is very convenient as it is on walking distance from Shinagawa station. It has a few hotels in this area all owned by Prince and each with a slightly different name. Be aware of this when looking for this hotel. The surroundings of the hotel are nice with a lot of green and rooms are decent.
