Tim Miguel S
Da Lat, Vietnam

review_body: This is a great choice in an area overflowing with hotels. The Japanese gardens are beautiful and the steak house on the grounds is available for a real treat: teppanyaki. You can luxuriate here for a price similar to a stark business hotel.

The hotel has very good service and a choice of restaurants. Rooms are large, which is a bit unusual for Tokyo. They are also quite comfortable. Hotel is situated in a quieter spot which makes things more relaxed than other parts of town.

This self proclaimed 'Hotel' has a 5 star view, a 4 star lobby, a 3 star room, a 2 star location, and a 1 star world cruise buffet. Do yourself a favor and don't stay here. It's way too far from the center of the city and we never had the desire to go out for dinner after relaxing in the late afternoon, because it's at least a 30 minute trip.

Rooms are fairly small, but that's standard in Tokyo. The space they have is well appointed and comfortable, and on a clear day the views were great. We could even see Mt Fuji in the distance! The breakfast buffet was good with a nice mix of Japanese and western style breakfasts. They have pleasant gardens to stroll around and a nice, albeit chargeable, public bath area. The location is superb, right by the station with access to all of Tokyo and beyond with the Shinkansen line.

I came here in May for business, and I certainly can't complain. We got the bus express to the hotel from the airport, it's a clean and cheap service, works well.The hotel is under refurbishment so there is a temporary entrance throught the conference centre, but this isn't really a hardship and check in was a smooth process.Rooms were nice and large and I can't say at any point during my stay I noticed or heard anything from the works going on that ditracted from my stay in the slightest.My room was very clean and pretty well appointed, nothing to complain about on that front.Breakfast was a little confusing, for the more US/European breakfast we had to go downstairs, walk through another eat in place and then come to our breakfast area. It was very small for the size of the hotel and involved a complicated system to get a seat (a cultural difference), so make sure you leave sufficient time to get there cand get your breakfast.The hotel is convenient for a couple of stations the largest being Shinagawa, from which you have access to literally the whole of Tokyo and indeed Japan.All the staff I came in contact with were very polite and helpful.Handy little 7Eleven on the basement level for any extras you might need.

If you can get a good deal on the rooms here, I would suggest this hotel.Location is just up the hill from one of the major JR stations in the Tokyo area, but set back enough that it's actually pretty quiet. For anyone flying into Haneda, being right outside Shinagawa station is great, since the train runs directly to that station, giving you immediate access to the hotel and the JR Yamanote line. The neighborhood itself is pretty quiet as well, so if you're looking for something with more activity I'd suggest taking a look at hotels around Shinjuku etc.Rooms are a bit larger than a lot of the other hotels I've been to in/around Tokyo, especially given the price. I always end up with one overlooking the garden, which is another cool feature of this hotel. It's definitely one of the older ones, but that is also part of the charm.Regarding the staff- there were a few people at the front desk with decent English skills every time I've been to this hotel, however your mileage may vary. In any case, they were always very helpful, even going out of their way to find a shop where I could get my bicycle fixed on short notice.As far as any problems go I haven't seen anything worth noting- other than taxis not actively pulling up to the hotel, but the staff has always been willing to call one for me, even if I ask for it way ahead of time.

I ve been their in March for business trip.Convenient for business trips. They provide pick up from airport.Comfortable rooms on executive floor.A lot of shops and restaurants around.Close to one of the international airport ...................

If you can get this hotel for less than JPY 14,000/night you should book it. It appears to be the oldest of the Prince hotels in the area but has terrific facilities and very convenient location to Shinagawa station that connects to the Shinkansen, the loop line, the Haneda airport line and the Narita express line.Excellent service, rooms are spacious and no noise at all. The gardens are beautiful and peaceful. The hotel even provides with free umbrellas for rainy days. And towels when you are back after forgetting to pick one. The hotel also has bus service to the airports.It is at 10 minute walk from the station with a moderate uphill section to reach it. You can use the elevators on neighboring Prince hotels for strollers and wheelchair access.

Have stayed three times at GPHT. The garden there is one of my favorite spots in Tokyo, so I prefer it to the Prince Shanagawa complex. The stuff is always amazingly friendly. The hotel felt secure during the earthquake we had one morning. The best part is the easy access to the Shinagawa train station and most of all - the beautiful garden. I like to practice my Taichi there early in the morning.

This is a great business hotel near Shinagawa Station in Tokyo. The staff are very friendly and the hotel is quite clean and comfortable. Westerners may find the rooms to be small but they are very comfortable and have electrical outlets where you need them.I would recommend this hotel if you are in the Shinagawa Station area of Tokyo.

Walking distance to Sinagawa station. Beautiful garden and fish pond. Hotel lobby looks promising but the rooms are standard, small and kinda old.Most of the staff does not speak English. The food variety is not that much. I wouldn't come back to this hotel

First, let me state that my review of this place is strongly colored by the fact that we stayed for three days at the Prince Sakura Tower next door, which is by far much better than this hotel, but is more expensive as well. Let me also state that all of the Prince hotels are impeccably run, and are staffed with the nicest, most attentive people you can possibly have at a hotel. That said, this is an old place, that although clean and well-run, desperately is in need of a refresh. (just FYI, my wife and I stayed in this hotel in 1988, and it seemed the same as last time. The only change we observed were the lovely heated toilet seats with the automatic butt washers!) The room fixtures, carpeting, beds, desks, are all very old and tired. The rooms are less than half the size of the rooms at the Sakura next door. The beds are very small also. (our king bed was really a queen..) The breakfast buffet had much less to offer than the Sakura, and was about the same price, so if you are paying for it (we didn't pay at the Sakura), you would be better off going next door for the buffet. Plus, the meals here were skewed more for Japanese tastes than the Sakura. The place was quite a bit noiser as well, less isolation with the halls and other rooms.

The Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa is an island of peace and quite in bustling Shinagawa. You can take the hotel's shuttle bus to and from Shinagawa Station or walk up the hill in five minutes. Well-appointed rooms are untypically spacious compared with Japanese standards, as they are larger than 20 squaremeters.The view of the adjacent Japanese garden is spectacular - especially during sakura, as the park is home to more than twenty different cherry trees.The restaurants of the hotel can be recommended - especially the tempura restaurant on the groundfloor which offers different set courses.If you are traveling from or to Narita Airport the Narita Express will take you straight to Shinagawa Station which is also on the JR Loop Line.

Stayed at the hotel a few weeks ago. Rooms are a decent size for Japan but overall they look and feel a bit tired. Not as close to the station as I would like and in the morning it is not easy getting a taxi if you want one as it is set back off the main road.Beautiful garden area though and the wifi worked very, very well.

It is an awesome experience staying at Grand Prince Takanawa in Tokyo. I enjoyed the Japanese Garden in the hotel. It is huge with a Koi Pond. The plants and trees are perfectly pruned and groomed. I thoroughly appreciated this great touch of providing guests to this great space. I recommend to anyone who enjoy being close to nature especially Japanese-style Gardens. The hotel is just a short distance away from Shinagawa Train Station. Super accessible for travelers of all genres - for holidays or business. This is THE station as it has fantastic connectivity. Ichi-ban Choice. I will want to go back to stay again.

This is a lovely hotel in a very good location if you arrive with the bullet train. Nice rooms, good fitness facilities in one of the other Prince towers via a lovely Japanese garden. A bit pricy like most Japanese business hotels but this one delivers value for money.

I happened to stay at the Grand Prince for a night and was pleasantly surprised at the size and quality of the rooms. The room had nice balcony overlooking trees giving nice & cozy feeling. I was initially checked into a smoking room, however, the reception staff were helpful enough to move me into a non-smoking room once I requested for a change. Highly recommended compared to other properties in the area that have much smaller rooms.

The whole furniture in the room was really old. For a Tokyo room was big as size, the only room they had was with twin beds so me and my wife had to sleep separately.Concierge was helpful, they provide info for all close attractions.Hotel was clean and close to Shibuya station (they offer a shuttle or you can take a walk downhill 5-10 minutes ).Overall it's worth staying in, the location is good.

I stayed here for only a night but it was excellent. It is located near the Shinagawa station. it is also fairly near Shibuya station and Tokyo tower. The hotel is a bit isolated. You have to walk up and down the hill to reach the station and the nearest convenient store. But the hotel itself was great. It has a park inside the hotel and if you don't want to go around tokyo (i.e. work stuff) you would still have a great time there. service was nice, the food was great and the rooms are spacious. This is definitely a recommended hotel. thumbs up.

A very good and luxurious hotel. Rooms are excellent, spacious and clean. Hotel staff are very pro and helpful. Breakfast is great. The location is not so great, but is close to metro station. View from the hotel room is amazing. Room facilities are great!! Can recommend to anyone willing to pay a little more for a comfortable stay.!!!

Stayed one night in this Hotel. Chosed hotel in Shinagawa coz it is near to Haneda Airport, paied 410 yen from Haneda to Shinagawa in Keiyu line, which was a local communte train that start / end @ Haneda airport.This hotel is a bit old and datad, my room is a standard twin room. Unfortunately they could only gave me a smooking room eventhough I've requested to have a non-smoking room during my booking.Good location, about 15 min walk to Shinagawa train station. Room either facing city (can see Tokyo tower at a distance) or facing a beautiful Japanese garden.Recommended for short stay. I would believe Grand Price Hotel Shin Takanawa would be newer and better, but paying higher price for it. So the choice is yours.

The rooms and decor are old. They charge an extra $40 per night for another guest. There is nothing on return. No extra towels, no extra glasses etc. Is close to the train station but it wouldn't make me want to stay there again.

I am here for about 4 days. Hotel has remarkable japan style garden. Their scenery is awesome. Located in suburban area, with least food counters around the hotel. However their rooms is quit small but compact. Like most hotel in Japan, their bed is a little bit hard than in my country.

Good hotel. Nice facilities. Very helpful people. Very nice garden. Soothing place. Very close to Shinagawa Station. But out of all Hustle and Bustle of the city. Very nice place in business district.......

This hotel is only 5 minutes walk from Shinagawa station, but the walk is up to the hill. Hotel itself is very nice, breakfast is really good. Room air conditioning didn't really work properly and they just couldn't deliver one simple iron to the room. Reception said that the hotel had only one iron and table.

My first visit to Japan. I honestly had no idea how incredibly helpful and polite a society Japan is. This hotel is incredibly helpful and efficient. Check in was fast and smooth, despite being a very busy day when we arrived. The hotel itself is probably 4 star. The bed comfort was good. Nice clean, soft sheets and a good mattress. The room was typically small and the TV was typically huge. Room service was fantastic and unobtrusive...unlike the US....where it seems as though their mission in life is to guilt you into over tipping. I didnt eat in the hotel as there are far to many choices around the city. The shuttle bus will take you to each of the Prince hotels...there are 4 in a very small area, various levels of spending and luxury. The Japanese garden is beautiful and out of busy times relaxing. Use the shuttle bus to get to Shinagawa rail/metro station...cost is free and will save you a hike. The hotel has a lovely view of the city because it is atop of a hillside.

This may not be the newest hotel on the block and what does that matter? The fact is this is a very comfortable hotel with truly excellent service.The two bars are excellent and staffed by again professional and helpful staff. 10/10The rooms were very comfortable and mine had a view of the beautiful extensive gardens which I recommend.
