review_body: I struggled with rating this hotel. There are so many great things about it, yet some basics are not up to snuff from an American viewpoint. In the end I had to go with a 4 star, although my actual rating would have been 3.7. The hotel site itself is wonderful. Two Prince properties face each other with a Japanese garden in between them (it's easy to go to a wrong one. the other one has the word "new" in its name). The hotel is perched on a hill which affords a great view of Tokyo. A Train station is just down the hill - a short walk. Which makes it easy to get around the city. As is normal in Tokyo, the train station support a big cluster of restaurants and shops. All of this makes for a great convenience. The hotel itself is somewhat dated in its architecture, but is not run down. Interior is, however, well passed its prime. Everything is spotless, but worn. Carpets are overdue for replacement. Furnishings are scratched and worn. In America this would not be tolerated, in a higher end property, but because the original furnishings were of pretty good quality, the hotel gets away with it. Still, you get a sense that the hotel is long overdo for a facelift. Rooms are smaller than normal for an American hotel room of the same class. The interiors are functional and clean, but at least 25 years old. As is normal for most of the Japanese hotels, the automated toilets spoil you with the warm spray, bide, and drying action. Shower is inadequate by American standards. Beds, while old, are very comfortable. Bedding itself is great. Everything has been maintained in a perfect working order. Service at the hotel is flawless. A number of staff are eager and willing to help and assist at every turn, always with a smile and a bow. The place runs like a well oiled machine. Restaurants on the premises are very good, but overpriced. WiFi is free and very strong. Overall, its a very good options for your business trip.

booked twin room for 5 nights. location good for shinagawa train station (we had jr rail pass and could get to kyoto, kamakura etc easily from.thus station). garden is lovely and a good walk in the morning. breakfast is okay, wide range but only enjoyed the fresh cut fruits and juices. room was large on 6th floor with view of the garden. i could work on the desk while mum uses the dressing table. minor complaint that the corridors are not ventilated, hot water flask takes forever to pump the water out, no iron in room. but i love the dressing gowns, fast checkin and clean carpets and comfy bedroom slippers. will stay again.

The room was excellent, and the staff very helpful. However, the lobby is clearly in need of some renovation.There was also a sushi restaurant where we had an excellent lunch on the last day, which we thoroughly enjoyed.Overall, I would say that this hotel is definitely good value.

Very good hotel, a bit expensive but room are normal size according to international standard and larger than japanese average.Buffet breakfast is quite good, good choice but nothing spectacular.Good serviceGood location at walking distance from Shinagawa stationNot to confuse with next door NEW Takanawa, very touristic busy hotel, full of people and poorer restaurants

Hotel is in desperate need of a refresh. Furniture is beaten up and the carpet is dirty. No yoga for me this week. Bath and bed are OK so happy about that. The staff are very professional and polite. If you are not going to spend much time in your hotel and just need a place to sleep and shower this is would be fine for that.

Schedule zammed and ended.up staying 3 different hotels for 6 days trip. This one was the last one and a solo stay. Good this was solo cuz the room was so small. A typical biz hotel size. The bathroom the same. Good view though since it is located at the top of the hill. A bit tricky to find since 3 prince hotels are located next to each other within 2 min distance. Great backyard and bbq restaurant. Very close to Shinagawa station. Has Airport bus stopping by the lobby. No photo of the room (too small to take any). Only view and bakcyard pond and the next door restaurant bldg.

✅ Shinagawa location is good ✅ checkin is fast ✅ you have work out which building it is because it's a pain ✅ if you don't speak Japanese English language skills are patchy ✅ wifi is good✅ room size is small ✅ rooms are clean ✅ expensive room rate for room type✅ for the location it's good but still expensive ✅ hmmm would not stay again

The Grand Prince Hotel is my preferred solution when I am in TokioClose to Shinagawa station is a perfect place to reach every corner of this cityGood breakfast, excellent meet restaurant nearby, very nice garden is a good quality hotel for your money

This hotel is perfect, beautifully set in gardens it is a delight to be there from the busy city. The staff cannot do enough for you the rooms are spacious and excellent and the food very good to suit all diets and tastes. Good value for money. I would go back there if I had the chance.

We were positively surprised by the standard of the hotel. Everything were working and were well thought through, in to every detail. The staff were very polite and kind. The hotel felt fresh and clean in a beautiful surrounding. The Katsura meat restaurant was expensive but well worth a visit. The food and the staff were outstanding. The bar in the hotel was very good with professional staff, good attitude and perfect drinks.Suggestions for even better stays:1. Toilet brush for cleaning the toilet 2. Freshly pressed fruit juice at breakfast 3. Shuttle service to and from the Sinangawa train station

It was nice stayed there on July30 to Aug 1.My wife,my 10 year old daughter and I stayed there for 2 nights.It was met warmly welcome and smooth check-in.Most staff were helpful and polite.Hotel was safe security system and fire alarm system,so we suffering safe while we stay.Room and bathroom style was a little bit out dated.Our room 454 had nice green garden view and clean enough.Room price was not cheap,but they were not provided compliment water bottles like other hotel in Japan.Sleep quality was soundly and nice.Morning breakfast for both 2 days ware fantastic and a lot of choice.Location was about 5 min walk to Shinnagawa station.Hotel location is easy to connect with Narita Express and many railway lines.Also 5 min walk to many restaurants and shops nearby.

Very nice hotel. Always very busy with lots of guest. Nevertheless check in and service is great.I stayed in a club room and in the lounge they offer a nice breakfast, however the evening snacks are rather limited.A plus point is that you have free drinks (beer etc.) from 5 to 9 pm while in most hotels it is limited to 2 hours. So no rush like in other hotels.They have many different restaurants so the choice is yours. I went to three different one’s and they all served very fine food.I went to the Marmolada, the main buffet restaurant. They offer a nice buffet selection with sushi made to order.Unfortunately the Japanese restaurant Shimiza is not mentioned in the restaurant list of Tripadvisor. It is worth of a five star rating. Delicious food.A place to return.

We booked this hotel mostly for convenience, and because the Shinagawa Prince was fully booked. In terms of location and convenience, it is great (See my recent review on the Shinagawa Prince regarding location). It is a little farther from the JR Shinagawa station than the Shinagawa Prince, but there is a shuttle that connects all four Prince hotels in the area. The downside is that the shuttle runs every 20 minutes, so you do have to plan accordingly. Still, it is a short walk to the train station, so we only needed the shuttle when lugging luggage. The rooms were slightly larger than the Shinagawa Prince, and similarly clean. Still, the room size is smaller compared to US hotels, but that always seems to be the case in Japan? Service was excellent. A plus was its proximity to the Takanawa gardens. It was nice to have this patch of green amid the otherwise bustling train station area. Like the Shinagawa Prince, there was an empty mini fridge in the room, and this fridge seemed to keep things at an appropriate temperature (The one in our room at the Shinagawa Prince seemed to be on the warm side--maybe that was a fluke?). Free WiFi, both Japanese and English language newspapers delivered daily. We did not go to any of the restaurants, but noticed that the lounge area served siphon style coffee. There are no gift shops in the hotel itself, but it is next to a convention hall and the New Takanawa hotel where there are about 5 mini shops, including a 7-11, a souvenir shop and a few dress shops. Since I often travel with a young child, proximity to a self serve laundromat (called 'coin laundry' or koin randorii in Japanese) is important. There was apparently one about a 10 minute walk away near a police station (koban), but I could not find it. There is also a playground across the street, if you are traveling with kids. Anyway, no complaints. I would stay here again or consider the other Prince hotels in the area such as the Sakura Tower which is slightly closer to the train station, and next to the garden

Very close to the train station which makes it handy to take the train from Haneda airport to Shingawa. Room is small but serviceable. Staff are very polite and the communal gardens between the brands allow for a nice peaceful stroll.

I have stayed at this hotel a couple of times over the past five years, and it is always the same. For a very reasonable (tokyo) price, you get a very standard room that cannot fit any luggage in it. The decor is stuck in the 70s, and the beige wallpaper is peeling off. The beds are hard and not springy, and the double room is two twins pushed together. There is no luxury here.The best part of this hotel is proximity to Shinagawa station, which is basically across the street, as well as the airport shuttle that stops directly in front of the hotel (reservations required).grand prince hotel takanawa

Stayed 4 nights at the Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa on arrival from UK and flight into Narita Airport. Apart from not being able to check in until early afternoon a great introduction to Japanese hospitality. Very courteous and helpful staff. Clean and tidy room. Lovely hotel garden. Nice and close to Shinagawa station and easy access to restaurants in the immediate area. Would be very happy to stay again.

Visited the Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa last week for one night. Flew into Narita took the Narita Express to Shinagawa hotel was a 5 minute walk from station. Had an early flight out of Haneda the next morning. Did not dine in the hotel. Staff recommended a nearby Yakatori restaurant which was awesome. Location perfect for getting around Tokyo by train. Hotel was very clean. Room was a bit outdated. Staff was great and very helpful. For aprox $200 it was a very good value even though we spent very little time at the hotel. Would stay again.

The hotel is conveniently located close from Shinagawa Station. Walking distance, but it seems there is shuttle service at certain time table. If you do not have much luggage like a backpack or sort of like that, it would not be a problem to walk up the road toward the hotel. However, if you need to drag a suitcase around, it may be a good idea to contact the hotel in advance about shuttle service from station.The room is spacious enough to open a suitcase, too. The room I slept in had a great garden view. Most probably, there are garden view rooms and tower view rooms. Although I booked a tower view room on the Internet, I ended up having a garden room. The tower view was the part I looked forward to, and also I wanted my friends to see Tokyo Tower from the room. However, they did not get the view, either. The front office staff did not tell me about it upon check-in where they should have because they sell rooms by categorising tower view and garden view. I could not be bothered to tell them after a long day. I am more than please to write that the room with garden view was good. I do not know how much difference in room size between the two types of the rooms, but I do not think it is fair that the hotel switches a room without telling that. They could have asked us for our preference at least.

This hotel is very conveniently located at Shinagawa Station - good for JR Yamanote line and Shinkansen. The beautiful garden makes it an oasis from the busy city. The staff are very courteous and helpful. Breakfast at the Patio restaurant was slightly overpriced for the quality so we resorted to buying cereal, milk, fruit and bread at Kinokuniya, a supermarket at the Takanawa exit of Shinagawa Station. This is a good hotel to have as a base in Tokyo - easy to access major tourist sites within the city as well as those further afield.

Rooms very nice , spacious , with bath . small balcony . excellent telly . staff very helpful , very friendly . I go again any time . Very nice Loi pond and garden , close to the station and main town . Tgi fridays nearby . Food excellent in all restaurants .scores 9/10 for me . Free wifi was a bonus . Useful for the local bullet train to visit Fuji Mountain . Also visit Tokyo zoo which is 20 mins away by subway train . j r line .

We chose this hotel for the location to the Shinagawa Station. We arrived via the Shinkansen and wanted somewhere close because we all had our luggages to carry. It's on a hill but you can go through the SAKURA Hotel lobby and go up to the Japanese Garden which leads you to the hotel. Our price included a breakfast buffet which can get crowded by 7:30am. The wait is about 5 minutes and it looked like the wait was longer closer to 8am. Breakfast had the typical American (eggs, bacon, cheese, etc) and Japanese (fish, miso soup, various tsukemono, natty, etc). Service to pick up our used plates were almost non existent while dining. But, something that we tolerated. The bus stops for the Airport Bus limousine for the is right outside the lobby which is a plus. This rate included free internet which we did not have any problems with connectivity. Our room was the 4 bedded Tatami room which gave all of enough space to open our luggages. There were just two chairs to sit. Otherwise, you are sitting on the floor. It's a typical Tatami room where you leave your footwear near the door. Front desk is helpful and can answer all your questions.

Three of the Prince hotels at Takanawa (the Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa, the Prince Hotel New Takanawa, The Prince Sakura Towers) share an exquisite Japanese Garden which - especially in cheery blossom season - are reason enough to stay here. Located a short walk from the Shinagawa Shinkansen station, the hotels are within half an hour of most major tourist attractions and business centers in the city. Rooms are larger than most city-center hotels.That's the good part.I have never experienced as much nickel-and-dime charging as I did at this property, starting from an usurious early check-in surcharge on hourly basis even though rooms were available and the hotel was aware I was arriving after a long overnight flight. The breakfast was below par in terms of the spread and nearly non-existent in service standards; newspapers on the stand were far less than table occupancy; only the rate charged was significantly higher. I would strongly recommend picking up breakfast supplies the previous night from the nearby Seven-Eleven as I did after my first experience.Not a hotel I would return to again. Perhaps I will try the other two that share the gardens, though - the scenic view is such a treat.

When I need to visit the Tokyo area, I like to stay in Shinagawa because it's a transportation hub for air, regular train, subway and bus services there. There are several better hotels in this area and Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa is one of them.Though it is not a brand new or recently refurbished hotel, it's been maintained reasonably well. It has rooms of more or less standard North American size (well, slightly smaller, but not significantly smaller) and that is nice when you need to relax or do some paper work in hotel.It takes about 7 to 8 minutes on foot from JR Shinagawa Station, but it's an uphill walk. If you don't like it, you can get a free shuttle bus service from Shinagawa Prince Hotel lobby area. I believe it runs every 20 minutes.Since it is located on a low hill, it commands a very nice view of Tokyo. Towards the northeast you have a great view of Tokyo and Tokyo Tower and beyond. On the other side of the building, you have a great view of its own Japanese style garden below.The hotel is served by an hourly airport bus to Narita International Airport. It's a door-to-door service to both Terminals 1 and 2 in about 70-75 minutes. I like this option much more than JR Narita Express or Keisei Skyliner services because it is door-to-door for about the same cost.

We found the Grand Prince Hotel a very pleasant place to base ourselves for our few days in Tokyo. It's location is just a few minutes walk (uphill) from the well connected Shinagawa Station which is simple and direct to get to from Narita Airport taking around an hour by train. There is a courtesy bus from the station to the hotel.The staff were great and although the hotel was very busy and nearly full they were able to change our room booking when we arrived.The rooms were good the size adequate considering the location, and spotlessly clean. There are several restaurants to choose from and many more locally just a short walk from the Hotel.We were fortunate to be travelling in late March as there was also a delightful garden which had a spectacular display of Sakura (Cherry Blossom).We would have no hesitation in returning.

The Grand Prince Takanawa located centrally to Shingawa station; just a few stops from Tokyo. The hotel is lovely and surrounded by beautiful gardens; and if you go in March it's Cherry BlossumSeason...during this time the hotel puts on a beautiful festival. (Check hotel for dates). Firstly, have to commend hotel staff and the exemplary service of Hiroyuki Shino. Aswe had a tour booked with JTB with arranged a hotel pick up. There are three or four Prince Hotels in the same proximity and unfortunately we were waiting at the incorrect one....when we realised without hesitation Hiroyuki drove us to catch up with the tour and didn't stop until he knew we made it!!We found it a little expensive 65,000yen (approximately 650aud) for two people to stay four nights (excluding breakfast). There were many things we found disappointing considering what we paid...  * Although staff could speak English; they were unable to answer our questions / queries.  * The room and bed are extremely small.  * The bed was extremely hard and uncomfortable. * The air conditioning unit bought in a cigarette smoke odour into our room. * Requested a late checkout and advised it would cost 1,600yen (approximately 16aud) per hour; never heard of being charged for this in all my travels!!! If you're thinking of booking I would suggest you reconsider.

I visit this hotel quite often, not staying but meeting and eating. Since our company has a corporate rate for staying at this hotel, we usually book it for a lot of people from overseas. There are 2 other hotels of the Grand Price Hotel New Takanawa and the Prince Sakura Tower Tokyo in this place. The Sakura Tower is the newest and Takanawa is the oldest. One of the remarkable features of these hotels is their garden. The garden is surrounded by these 3 hotels. One of the best seasons is spring, because you can enjoy cherry blossoms in this garden. There is an approaching road from Shinagawa Station to Grand Price Hotel Takanawa. It will be full of cherry flowers both sides of the road. There is a lounge called "Komyo Lounge" on the first floor in Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa. You can see its beautiful Japanesse garden with sky from the huge glass wall from the floor to the high ceiling, which gives you relaxing and enjoyable time. It is really beautiful in spring and autumn. In the evening you can see beautiful and mysterious cherry blossom with lightening up. On the other hand, you can see other cherry blossoms from the Itarian restaurant "Ristorante Caffè Ciliegio" in Sakura Tower. I tried to book this restaurant when the cherries fully bloomed but could not do it as expected. The cherry trees are on the hill which you can see from the restaurant magnificently. I don't know how to book the box seats equipped on the hill. If you can book it successfully, you can really enjoy cherry blossoms under the cherry trees. Price-wise Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa is cheaper and we usually arrange to book it. But Sakura Tower is quite new and clean and has magnificent view of cherry blossoms from the room in spring. Some of them who stayed both in the Sakura Tower and the Takanawa strongly recommed the Sakura Tower because it is not only new and clean but also size of the rooms are bigger than the Takanawa. It is nearer to Shinagawa Station and shopping places near and inside Shinagawa Station.

The room was larger than I was expecting for a room in Tokyo. It looked like it was about 15 - 20 years old, but at the same time, the room (I particularly noticed the bathroom) were clean and in good repair. Grout and sealant almost looked like they were recently redone, by someone very particular about their work. The hotel is in an excellent location, just across the street, AND something I wasn't told before, for a 6 foot tall guy, 350 paces up a hill, to the hotel entrance. Not a problem for 1 or 2 trips to anywhere, but if you make multiple trips to your hotel room, it can be annoying. There is a shuttle bus, but you do have to make reservations for it, going down the hill, and it is first come first served going up the hill. (Every 20 minutes).The breakfast(included in my tour package), was Western and Japanese. I do not know how much it cost, but there was a good selection of Western items, better than some other hotels I stayed at in Japan.The big negative for me was when I first entered the room, it smelled like someone just took a dump in the bathroom. It was quite strong, even for a who works around animal manure. Fortunately, I knew exactly what the problem was as it happens sometimes in our basement. The trap in the floor drain had dried up, and I only had to add a few glasses of water to the floor drain, and the smell disappeared in about 15 minutes.

Located near Shinagawa station which is a stop for Shinkansen and Narita Express.A walk up the hill or use the hotel shuttle. Rooms are a good size for Tokyo. Hotel has delightful gardens. With a number of Prince hotels in close proximity it can be confusing so check your directions. Staff were excellent. Hotel has dressing rooms if you want to change into or out of your travel clothes. Try Anna Millers down the hill opposite the station for breakfast.

The surrounding park alone around the hotel deserves a special mention, with all the traditional Japanese gardens, houses and scenery. The rooms are excellent, the food great, with many varieties, and the service very good.

Very big Hotel with several "parts" nearby. The individual parts of it have different Ratings but one can walk between them. Then entrance hall is quite impressive and there is a nice bar nearby.The Hotel troughout has an overage Japanese cleanliness and the rooms are OK. Nothing Special although they are not THAT small considering the fact that the Hotel is in Tokyo. The area around the Hotel is quite nice and the Train Station is just 5 minutes down the hill.Breakfast is OK but nothing more so in total it is an slightly above average Business Hotel.

Prince hotel in all means:Old 4.5* hotel.Spacious.Japanese service.Amazing garden.Location close to perfect regarding Shinagawa station.Some facilities are calling for a renovation but this is tokyo after all. built and maintained in the 1980's....

The grand prince Takanawa is ideally located close to Shinegawa station; which brings you fast to anywhere in Tokyo. The hotel itself is huge, it is composed of several high buildings with rooms connected by a small but extremely lovely garden. Staff is friendly and efficient. Rooms are space wise very good, well maintained, very clean but look quite outdated. Breakfast is expensive.

Stayed this with my husband for one night, we try to find a hotel that close to Tokyo station.the location is good, the garden is very beautiful and nice,make sure you take a picture. the hotel lobby was nice as well, the lighting is very good make you feel you are in five star hotel.I did not expect this at all, so we take this as a nice surprise, they also have a free wifi which is very nice. the room was small and dark.I do not like the rooms, if you decided to stay here maybe do not choose a standard room (upgrade).maybe next time, if we are go back to Japan we are going to try other room in this hotel.

I visited this hotel from Jan 10 to Jan 14, the location is good. You do not need to walk along the hill to the hotel, you should access 2nd floor of the Sukura tower (sister hotel) and walk to the Japanese garden which connects to the Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa.The room is tidy and clean, the view is good. The environment is peace. It is recommended to visit it again. The staff is polite and helpful. The shuttle bus service is provided for accessing the nearest JR station and the Airport.

I was in this hotel for 3 days during a business trip and the hotel it's nice, rooms are bigger than other hotels in Japan and it has an awesome japanese garden.From the point of view of a european person the bathroom was ok, nothing to complain I wouldn't say it was awesome.The staff was very nice and helpful for any question request we had.The only problem we had with this hotel was the location. It's very close to Shinagawa station what is cool but there are several prince hotels around and it was a bit tough to find this one the day we arrived.

My last Tokyo business trip i booked the prince takanawa .... The hotel is huge with hundreds of rooms and several ancillary hotels in the perimeter of the takanawa ecosystem. Rooms are ok but really bad was the huge breakfast canteen , more a company canteen for thousands workers in a factory than a VIP hotel restaurant ... Next time ok for the Hotel, close shinagawa railways station and comfortable but mcdonalds for breakfast. Nice the small lounge bar at 39 floor with outlook on Tokyo tower ...

Nice location - close to Shinagawa station and surrounded by green area - and that's it.The hotel itself, as well as rooms are quite battered. Try to book rooms of higher categories, standard rooms are awful.  Restaurants in the hotel are overpriced.

That's what they about three most important things in hotel business- location, location and location. Grand Price nails it by being walking distance to Shinagawa station, which connects you to rest of Japan by the high speed Shinkasen network. Not very from Haneda airport and extremely well connected to rest of the Tokyo. The shuttle bus service from Shinagawa to hotel adds further convenience.Rooms are fair sized as per Japan standards, Americans and several European/ Asians may find them smaller but for Tokyo, they will surely be in higher end of size range. The hotel is not new and you can see that in some areas where the finishes are not great but all in all the rooms are fully functional, clean and sell stocked. There is nothing much to find fault about.My only grumbling point was that there was no drinking water in the rooms and one has to buy it from the vending machines.Breakfast was good and had quite a good range of non- Japaneses options. The station can be accessed by passing through the Japanese garden, which in itself is a big plus since its maintained well and deserves some attention.The hotel serves mainly foreign travelers and staff spoke English well. Overall there was nothing much to complaint or but nothing out of expectations, which is not bad either.

Arriving from Haneda Airport in Tokyo is the best, the hotel is far from Narita.This is an older building, well kept and maintained, the rooms and bathrooms are rather small, but clean and well equiped.Breakfast buffet offers a wide selection but not as wide as other hotels I have visited in the east.The most impressive part is the beautiful garden, it is a great place to chill.Prices are expensive as anything else in Japan, and taxis are a killer.

I use this hotel while I'm on biz trip in Tokyo and i will continue due to the great location/connection to Shinagawa station, quite and nice garden. In my view, rooms will need some renovation soon, particularly doors and walls.

I stayed at the Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa for 2 nights, and had quite a pleasant stay.The hotel itself has the dignity of an old establishment, and the rooms are not modern, but still comfortable. The service was excellent, my room was spacious and comfortable, breakfast was nice, but the wifi at the room was not fast enough.The hotel is close to the Shinagawa train station (up the hill, so you might want to take the way back on taxi). It has a lovely garden, and I enjoyed my stay.

Okay... The price is good, but what else do you get besides the room? - No water- No gym (wait.... there's a mediocre one that they charge you JPY 2100 for) - Breakfast... well, if you paid for it - Location that is 30 min cab from anywhere. The rooms don't even come with bottled water. This hotel is truly confusing. Staff isn't helpful; they won't send you an invoice after your stay. Room service is poor-- only one or two english speakers; the internet occasionally decides not to work. Pay a couple extra bucks and stay somewhere else.

Stay 8 nights at this hotel for holidays with family. Everything is perfect from the moment I started to book this hotel till I checked out from this hotel1) Prompt reply on my queries email before I was in Tokyo.2) Direct limousine bus service from the airport, stop directly in front of the hotel lobby. You can book the limousine bus service from the hotel for going to airport.3) Fast check-in and friendly staff ( Provide children toothbrush and slippers upon check-in and will try their best to help you)4) Room is clean and with a nice view, facing Tokyo Tower ( better to request when booking)5) Free Wi-Fi ( Important as allowed me to check the weather forecast and train status as there was typhoon in Japan when I was there.)6) Good location as mentioned by others, about 10 min walk to Shinagawa Station, which will easily bring you to other locations ( or alternative you can take the free shuttle bus with 15 min interval, but need to book in advance)7) Nice restaurant in the hotel ( though a bit expensive in my opinion) 8) Restaurants, fast food and convenient shops nearbyWith all the good things above, definitely will choose this hotel for my future trips to Tokyo.

About 10 minutes walk up a hill from Shinagowa station, there is a shuttle bus you can pick from the station by the taxis, wished we knew that when we were dragging our luggage up a hill in the humidity after a long flight from uk. Lovely gardens with shrines and pond. Popular convention & wedding hotel, so be prepared to be anonymous. As with all large Japanese hotels they are inflexible about the checkin times and make you wait till 2pm. So we unpacked our stuff to find clean clothes after a long flight in the foyer using the lobby loos as a changing room, not the best start. The guest relation lady was very helpful in organising us onto the grey line bus tour and arranging a hotel pick up. We were booked into a twin smoking room, 429(?) not our choice but it did have a fab view of the Tokyo tower - spectacular at night. It had free wifi and bbc news on tv. Remember to book yourself on the shuttle bus to save yourself a steep walk to the station. Quiet location up on hill. If you have someone who can compare the online price of the Japanese website to see if it is cheaper than the English price, worth doing.

Pros: Location, Price, Ameneties, Noise levelCons: Baffling rules, tired decor, inconsistent staff attitudeThis hotel was a strange experience. It wasn't good or bad overall but had high and low points. The location for example was superb and quiet given the fact it was in Tokyo, but various rules over petty things are just baffling. Added to that if you've never been there before you can spend a long time trying to find the place and it can be a frustrating experience.Breakfast is decidedly low-end. It's okay for a business traveller but it's not going to set your world alight.

There are 4 Prince hotels in close proximity with a very nice shared garden with koi pool. I used to stay here on business and did so again for a holiday with my partner. The decor (lobby and rooms and bathrooms) is rather dated but the upside of this is that it is better value than the other 3 hotels, which are much smarter. Shinagawa is a pretty good place to base yourself as the station is only 5 mins walk and has good connections plus shinkansen (bullet train). You'll get more space than for the same price in Shinjuka say. There are some good restaurants the other side of the station if you want to eat locally. The hotel restaurants are very good but pricey.The limo bus from Narita is about 1h30m.

I stayed here for three nights and really liked the hotel. Close to Shinagawa Station, and a regular shuttle runs between the three Prince Hotels and the station every 15 minutes. Check in and check out were easy and the room was much bigger than I anticipated, and comfortably furnished. I had a great view of Tokyo from my room, and the Japanese gardens which separate the three properties are really beautiful and tranquil. Breakfast was excellent with a good choice of western and Japanese. The omelette chef made a great omelette using just chopsticks. The bed was very comfortable and the shower terrific. Being so close to Shinagawa station was a bonus for me and I would definitely be happy to stay there again.

i stayed here three nights on a recent business trip to Japan. I have stayed at the other Prince hotels nearby, so I was familiar with the area. The hotel cannot be seen from the east entrance to the station, so unless you take the free shuttle bus from the hotel (runs every 15 minutes) just turn right and walk about 150 meters. There is a road that takes you to the Prince Sakura Tower (which can be seen) and the Grand Prince. There is also a hotel with a similar name - either the Grand Prince New Takanawa (or Shin Takanawa). It's easy to get the wrong location. The helpful,staff will point you to the right one. Once you finally get there, you're rewarded with an ideal location. Some of the rooms have a view of the Tokyo Tower, which other hotels may not have. There's a shopping mall nearby and a number of restaurants where Japanese is not required. The room was comfortable and roomy by Japanese standards. I slept pretty well, and liked having a few days in the area after a string of one-night stays the week before. I'd come back here on a future visit to the area. I liked it better for comfort, but it's about 10 minutes walk from he station and up a big hill.

Convenient location near to Shinagawa Station in Tokyo. Shuttle bus runs between the hotel and station at regular intervals. Helpful service. Awesome garden. Reasonably sized room. It's one of the older Japanese hotel properties so spartan and utilitarian. But everything works.A regular choice for my business trips to Tokyo.

There is a small cigar lounge with an excellent selection of Cubans and a wide range of single malt scotch. Great prices on the smokes. Although small, the lounge offers an an intimate setting for 2 and other areas where you could have a small group 4-5 comfortably. The lounge opens at 5pm.

Was there on a business trip, 8 nights , found friendly staff and roomsmall but comfortable.Not expensive overall, it's 5 minutes walk to Shinagawa station, I personally never tried taxis or bus and enjoyed going there by foot.Breakfast was also very good.

Stayed here one night while waiting for a connecting flight, and it's ideally situated. I arrived into Shinagawa on the Shinkashen, walked out of the station, and was met by the hotel's courtesy bus. The next morning, a short bus ride and I was back at the station for the 30mins train to Haneda airport.Being right next to Shinagawa, it's pretty centrally located to go anywhere in Tokyo, and the hotel itself is lovely - clean, well equipped. Everything you'd expect form a nice four star - but at a cheap rate!

The Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa is in walking distance to Shinagawa train station (metro lines, JR line and Shinkansen), with comfortable rooms (even if not so large...) and good service. Don't miss a visit to the hotel garden (while going to - or coming back from - Shinagawa station by foot): it is a very pleasant location!We enjoyed a wonderful view of the Tokyo Tower from our room, which had wi-fi also.Nice stay!

We stayed at the Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa for two days in October 2013. I did choose the hotel, because it is easy to reach from both airports - Haneda and Narita - by limousine bus service and it is in walking distance to Shinagawa train station with access to the JR rail network (even the Shinkansen bullet train stops there). As it was my first time in Japan, I was a bit nervous that I could get lost while searching the hotel in the middle of the night, but it turned out to be easy to find. The hotel is part of a complex of 4 different Prince Hotels with a beautiful Japanese garden and walkways connecting the buildings. After walking up a hilly road from the train station with our suitcases we arrived at the wrong Prince hotel, but the concierge was very helpful and led us to the right hotel where we had the booking. The room was small for international standards, but functional and very, very clean. We had a splendid view of Tokyo Tower and the Sengakuji Temple (famous for the story of the 47 Ronin). The hotel staff spoke good English and was friendly and helpful. Internet worked well, although having to use a LAN connection felt a bit outdated. I loved the special atmosphere of the hotel, which is very busy with lots of weddings taking place, so you can see women wearing Japanese kimonos. There a plenty of cafes, tea houses and restaurants to choose from within in hotel complex. We were very happy with the breakfast at the coffee shop called Edelweiss Cafe.

Easy train connection from Haneda this Grand Prince Hotel. There are 4 different Prince Hotels in a block. Several of them share gardens & connecting walkways. This one was very clean & neat. Rooms are a bit small (fairly standard for Japanese hotels!), but ours had a wonderful view of the Tokyo Tower and 2 comfortable twin beds. Large closet, safe & good sized bathroom made it a comfortable room for a 2 night stay. Our Japanese friends were our guides so we didn't have to worry about the logistics, but the train system is awesome and easy connections to anywhere you want to go. Didn't eat in the hotel, but the restaurants looked great. All the staff were friendly and helpful.

With a very lovely Japanese Garden. The rooms were very comfortable. The staff were very helpful, even helped us arrange for a tour. Breakfast buffet was great. Good location, restaurants and convenient stores nearby. Money exchange machine inside the hotel makes it so convenient !

everything up to the mark . service prompt . surroundigs green and cool. breakfast excellent . rooms spacious. bathrooms very clean and tidy.railway station at walking distance. airport not far away. What else one needs.

I could not believe that this hotel with its beautiful gardens was in Tokyo! What a beautiful refuge. This is one of three hotels on the same property and not the newest. Service was exceptional at the desk. The breakfast was wonderful. The rooms are spacious and comfortable. Take the shuttle bus from Shinagawa Station - especially if you have bags to carry!! We enjoyed walking on the grounds and in the neighborhood. The price for our stay was very reasonable. Everything you need! We will stay here in the future.

Everything was just right and very Japanese in the best of service. Nothing was too much trouble. The staff especially are superb. Most spoke excellent English. Very comfortable rooms and the location was very good. Frequent shuttle busses to Shinagawa Rail Station- a main hub and a stop for the Bullet train, made it easy to get to anywhere in Tokyo. My choice for my next stay in Tokyo.

We stayed 2 nights in this hotel when we recently visited Tokyo and we were not disappointed. They accommodated our request for early check-in and extra towels and pillows. The check in was quick and very courteous. The room was big (for Japanese hotels) and more than adequate for triple occupancy. And the price was quite reasonable for Tokyo. Our room was facing the gardens in between 2 other hotels. In the mornings and late evenings, it is nice to stroll around the gardens, s it had a very relaxing atmosphere. The hotel has a complimentary shuttle service to/from Shinagawa station but one must know the schedules beforehand otherwise it is long walk uphill to the hotel from Shinagawa station.

We stayed 6 nights - early April for Cherry Blossom. There is a shuttle to the MTR Station - Shinagawa but it is only a 5 minute walk out the back gate (we never used the shuttle). As of the 1st April 2014 - they now provide free Wifi in the room - signal strength and speed were very good. The breakfast in the Patio Restaurant is very good & reasonable value. We had a room with City View - looking at Tokyo Tower - very good. We only had 1 complaint which we did mention to Guest Relations - that was that there was a grate over a drain on the side of the carpark that was bent - everytime a car, bus, taxi, truck etc... ran over it, you go Bang, Bang - this was so load it kept us awake - If they could replace the grate on the drain - they would have earned an Excellent. For this location we can visit everywhere - Shinagawa is a main station for the Shinkansen, it is also on the Yamanote Line - the main loop line in Tokyo1 ticket to get on and off at any of the 29 stations is Y140 or a day pass to get on and off as often as you like is Y750.The Tokyo Morning Television Show was doing the weather in the garden behind the hotel because of the Cherry Blossom trees - they are spectacular. The Limousine Bus from Narita was at least 1.5hrs - so be prepared for that.But it was a great location and if we go back to Tokyo we will stay here again.

From the airport you can purchase a "limo bus" ticket that will take you straight to the hotel (around 1.0 - 1.5hrs) and you get a very gracious welcome and efficient check-in. The rooms are smaller as expected for Japan but really comfortable and with all the amenities except a minibar (fridge is there but empty). However a quick walk through the garden to the sister hotel (New Grand Prince) and you will find a 24/7 shop where you can stock on snacks and drinks for your stay. I was lucky enough to be at the hotel during the bloom of the Cherry Blossom Trees and the Japanese garden is stunningly beautiful, especially at night when it is all lit up.As I was there on business and in Tokyo everyone takes the train it was nice and convenient as there is a station at the bottom of the hill which made it convenient to go to work (mind you the hill looks very steep when you come back in the evening :-). Breakfast is great with a huge variety to choose from and very friendly staff who all speak English so communication is easy in the hotel. If you cannot decide what you want for dinner and where to go I highly recommend you discuss any ideas with the head concierge who will not only recommend but will even book a table for you (if you want to eat outside of the hotel)Overall a very enjoyable stay.

Too bad we only spent 1 night at this hotel and checked out early in the morning to catch the first train to Narita from Shinagawa. We would love to spend more time to explore the hotel though. The room is big for Japanese standard. Our room is facing the city and the view of Tokyo Tower is magnificent. Check-in was smooth although the receptionist didn't even smile. We were escorted to our room by a very friendly staff who answers all our questions and needs. The garden at the back of the hotel is very relaxing. A walk to Shinagawa Station could take between 10 to 15 minutes but they provide shuttle bus to all Prince hotels in the vicinity. Will definitely come back to this hotel.

Perfect business travel hotel, liked this better than Prince Shinagawa... rooms bigger, garden is nice etc. Maybe a bit older looking but clean, nice.. all in order. WIFI is free, but you need to rent the modem.. 1000YEN / stay. No ironing board tah the room, must ask from the reception. Stuff is really friendly and helpful.

My wife and I spent two nights at this hotel during a tour of Japan, and whilst the rooms could do with a make over, the public areas were fine. WI FI is only available in the very large foyer at the moment but this is about to change in April when it should be accessible in all rooms. The breakfast was OK, even if you are not keen on Japanese food at this time of day. Maybe a lack of fresh fruit, however, this was the case all the hotels we stayed in during our tour. We ate in the Wakatake Tempura Restaurant one evening and had a delicious meal. As a hotel resident one got discount for some of the set meals, need to show room card, which worked out to be quite reasonable for a good authentic dinner. As for the rooms, yes, they are on the small side, but nearly all hotel rooms in Japan are small. A little research before travelling would have highlighted this fact. What little contact I had with reception staff was fine, as was with the restaurant waiters and concierge.

My family stayed here for 4 days and 3 nights and we were treated like a prince (not king) and princess (not queen) simply because my expectations is more on the High end, the name being Grand Prince nonetheless our vacation became memorable because of the "all in one" concept of this hotel. Meaning, there is already a typical Japanese koi garden at the back of the hotel where kids can play and wander the greeneries after a long day's tour, a shuttle bus every 15 minutes that leads you to Shinagawa MTR station since the hotel is situated along the residential hill side village of takanawa, a good breakfast buffet at passion restaurant, a fast complimentary Wifi at the hotel lobby (room has a fee), and a decent room (not grand) in terms of comfortable beds but a typical outdated furnishing (tube TV, no espresso machine, flat iron for pressing and fridge supplies) which I think is typical to a timeless business hotel like this not to mention the fabulous toilet seats (japanese standard push button bidet) . Crib is provided for my infant upon request and so is the sofa bed and the bell captain at the reception is very much willing to help for anything you ask from the tours, to transportation and food. For tourist with a family in tow, we never got lost when we tried going to Shibuya with the able assistance of the bell captain. If you want a fast food, french fries and burger for kids are within reach also in nearby Hollywood Mall. The downside of the hotel is the noise coming from the lift since we were given a room near to the elevator and housekeeping room but just fine since we were all tired after a long day's tour. Also, the racist young driver of the shuttle which initially barred us in the bus at MTR station but later gave in after showing that we are hotel guests (old driver is very polite btw) and the lack of english newspaper which is complimentary to most hotels provided every morning. Shuttle by the way runs from 8am to 945pm thus if you are coming from a late flight or tour, walking uphill is a challenge or a taxi is viable option.

Good:Nice clean roomsFriendly staff (typical for Japan)Excellent breakfast QuietNot so GoodIf you pay for breakfast - a little expensiveOff the track...a 10 to 15 minute walk to train station. They have a shuttle but if you are out late (past 10PM) you must take taxi (less than 1000Yen) if you do not want to walk.I have been to many hotels in Japan and this is one of the better ones (Business Travel). I just wish it was closer to the main strip so I did not have to use shuttle or taxi. Other hotels in area seem less relaxed but are in the middle of the main areas so you just walk out hotel while this one requires a little ride/walk to get to the shopping and places to eat.

I stayed in this hotel not long ago, for a short stay in Tokyo and then flying to Hokkaido. When I first came to this hotel, I got lost a few times. It is quite annoying, since there were a few hotels under this group. When I got to the reception, the staff were very affable. They spoke English, but don't expect it to be perfect. All the lobby and restaurant staff spoke English, but housekeeping did not. When I first got to the hotel, I could not believe how European the lobby looked. It was huge, and it was the only place that wifi worked. In the rooms, there was only a landline. When I got to the room, it wasn't very big. It was either because it was a typical Japanese hotel rooms (famous for being small) or the fact that I did order an extra bed. It was still nice though, with a table and a chair. The beds were really comfy, too. There was also a nice little balcony, and mine had a great view. The toilet was not exactly gigantic, but it was well equipped. The water also had a nice pressure. The only bad thing was that the closet was very hidden and it did not have a door. It was very difficult to get your clothes out, but there were still clean hangers laid out for you. There was a convenience store on the bottom floor, with lots of stuff to buy. In the basement there was a restaurant, which you need to have breakfast coupons. The great thing about these coupons are that you can use them on room service breakfast, which was very continent for me, since I left early on the last day. There was a shuttle bus to both airports, and to the JR Station (railway). The thing about both, it that you have to book for them. Even though they had a shuttle bus for the station, it wasn't that far away, around a five minute walk. You can see the hotel from the station, too. If I ever stay in Tokyo again, I would probably go to this hotel again, since it was quite convenient and comfy.

A good business hotel. Calm and quiet. Good friendly service, big rooms, It is located in Shinagawa which is a good area in Tokyo to stay in due to the excellent logistics from there. Yamanote line, Shinkansen and Narita Express all stops at Shinagawa station. The hotel is 5 minutes walk from the station. The interior is starting to become a Little bit worn down and outdated but thats the only negative. The Beautiful Japanese garden outside makes up for that.

Arrive the 21st December 2013 evening. Best staffs ever. From the the moment we arrived at the hotel, all the staffs are so helpful, cheerful and guided us all the way. The garden is beautiful and the hotel is good size for Japanese standard. We have two separate rooms. One for my sons and the other for us. The Shinagawa Station was not that far away. A nice 5 minutes walk down or up the slope. Will be going around town today.

You can get better for your money. The rooms are like an old motel. The curtains and furnishings are depressing. The rooms are tiny. The bathroom is decent but there was a fixture above the shower that was all covered in dust in the cracks. The people working the front desk were really stuffy and not really helpful in assisting us. For the money I would look around for something more modern.

This hotel is a great value for money and very reasonable for Tokyo. Comparable to a best western type of hotel. Our room was clean, quiet and spacious. The staff were very helpful and friendly. It is between two subway stations ( walk 5 min to Shinagawa, 10 min to Takanawa). Make sure you get a suica pass at Shinagawa station then you can use any of the three separate subway lines around Tokyo. The JR line from Narita airport goes right to Shinagawa. Or you can take the airport limousine (big bus) between the hotel and airport. The restaurant and bar at the hotel are a bit pricey, but there is a good variety of restaurants and a grocery store nearby, anything from a 7-11 or mcdonalds to more formal. The only downside is that if you want to go bar hopping in shibuya etc, the subway stops at midnight, so prepare to stay out all night. Our only difficulty is when we first arrived we found there are several hotels in this complex and went to the wrong one (best directions I can give is it's up the hill from the 7-11). We enjoyed our stay and would happily stay there again.

My wife and I stayed here as part of a package tour.Loved the fact it is a short walk from JR Shinagawa as we had JR passes and even getting around Tokyo was easy.Loved the beautiful gardens and peaceful areas, such a contrast from the chaos of the city!!The room was big enough and clean and quiet.We ate in the hotel and had no complaints about the quality or the cost. The staff were always friendly and helpful and found the hotel a great place to stay. We would definitely stay again on our next visit to Japan.

Travelling with five other friends and family found this hotel good value for money wifi Internet to your room 1000 yen for your stay acceptable. Shuttle buses frequently to and from SHinagawa station very convenient the walk is not far but is up a reasonable slope. Showers hot and water plentiful. We did have three rooms but all were on separate floors.

Stay at this hotel for 2 week back in September and it was enjoyable.Had checked-in one day later than indicated on reservation through a third party site. While staffs at Takanawa were unable to locate our reservation, they offered us a room as it was getting late and assured us that they will look into the issue and contact us in the morning. Surely issued was resolved by morning – stress free!Not all staffs spoke fluent English, but made great effort to accommodate their guest’s needs.Take advantage of their Green Room service if you do not plan to receive room service on a daily basis. Basically Green Room service is to request for no room service and in return you will receive a 500yen/day voucher for spending at their restaurants / souvenir shop on premise. Make sure to fill out the form for this service and hand it in to front desk by 9 am.Narita Airport tip – While Shinagawa station is walking distance from the hotel and many train transportations are available to Narita. The hotel offers a shuttle service to Narita Airport for 3,500yen (if I remember correctly). It worked out for my party and I as we had several large and heavy luggages that we did not want to stroll to the station. The way to the station consist of a down hill walk, using escalators or stairs to arrive at Shinagawa station. One-way train ticket to Narita would be about the same price as the hotel shuttle.Hotel room is very basic and furnishings are out of date. For me it was not a concern, at the end of a day, all I need is a hot shower, nice cold AC room and a comfortable bed. Wi-fi is only available at the lobby – but if you are on a vacation is there really a need to be on the internet 24/7?The price per night is a bit pricy, but I would check-in again for the reasons that the hotel is conveniently located by Shinagawa station, with many restaurants and friendly and helpful staffs.

We had 6 nights in the hotel - we enjoy every moment. Although the hotel is not a new one it is very pleasant and comfortable. The stuff is very helpful - wish to help you with all they can.Location - yes, the hotel is located on top on a small hill - there are about 3 shuttles every hour to the Shinagawa station but for us it was not a problem to go, 10 minutes, by foot. It is not fit for whom who have difficulties with walking. The room was nice and the garden around the hotel is great. Shinagawa is a very big and crowded station -many trains , to various places in Japan, stops there - It makes it very easy for tourists.

Everything about this place was pretty nice. Except you get a false sense of style when you walk into the lobby. everything looks pretty cool, updated and nice. But as soon as got off the elevator on my floor, I quickly realized that the updating stopped at the lobby. The hallway had dingy carpet and smelled pretty funky. The room didn't smell at all but everything seemed very old.As far as location goes, this is a decent spot for business travel. But, If you want to hit any great restaurants, do any type of nightlife or shopping, you will need to take a train to more happening areas.

Arrived in the evening at Tokyo Narita with a flight at 6:55am the next morning out of Tokyo Haneda airport. I chose this hotel due to the ease of getting there from Narita and its proximity to Haneda, and of course the price. 1 night cost 17,800 yen on a Sunday in Aug 13 (Tokyo is hot and humid then, even at night).- Staff & CleanlinessStaff are friendly and happily organised my taxi for me at 4am. They speak enough English to get by. I don't speak a word of Japanese and didn't have any problems.Hotel is clean as you'd expect. The lobby is big and has a few nice restaurants including garden dining.- Location & CommuteThe hotel is clean and conveniently located a few minutes walk from Shinagawa train station, which has express trains from Narita airport (~45min). From Shinagawa station there are trains on that are a short trip to Shibuya (12min) and Shinjuku (19min) stations, which are handy. The Narita express (NEX) for 3,500 yen includes a an express ride from Narita airport to Shinagawa, and a 1,000 yen train pass which can be used for the aforementioned trips. Good value and convenient. Look up the JR East Railway site.The taxi ride to Haneda airport took about 30min and cost 5,840 yen.The most confusing part is that there are a number of 'grand' & 'prince' hotels right next to each other so make sure you have a map so you know exactly where to go. I first went to the 'grand prince hotel NEW takanawa'.- InternetFree internet is always a plus! However the wifi in my room didn't seem to connect but I didn't investigate as I had my laptop for a speedy lan connection. They also have a full business centre in the lobby.- SummaryOverall a comfortable stay for a decent price. Would stay again.

I stayed here for five days and it was a satisfactory experience. The hotel could do with a bit of an update as it was looking a little tired. That said the service was excellent, the rooms were clean, there was plenty of choice for food both within the hotel and within walking distance of the hotel. The prices are reasonable and overall it is in a good location as it is very close to the station. The staff were incredibly helpful as it was my first time in Tokyo and I was feeling a little overwhelmed!!I would definitely stay here again. A good experience.

This is one of several Prince hotels in Takanawa, less than 10 minutes walk from the very busy Shinagawa Station.Key Points from my stay- Excellent location close to Shinagawa station- The staff are very helpful offering excellent Customer service- The public areas very relaxing and the gardens are beautiful. - Disappointingly, bedrooms are showing their age and are in desperate need of refurbishment. The one that we were allocated had a great view of Tokyo Tower, but was very small and lacked WiFi (this was available free of charge in the lobby)- Restaurants very expensive but very good Really, this hotel is set up to cater for the Japanese businessmen and weddings and to a certain extent is trading on past glories. However, the enviable location, excellent service and good value (for Tokyo) make this an excellent base for a few days sight seeing in Tokyo. I would strongly recommend it providing you understand its age.

The location of this hotel is a 10 minute walk from Shinagawa station. It is clean, the staff is polite and they all speak English fairly well. The garden is very pretty and offers a quiet respite. There are many weddings on weekends there. The breakfast buffet is good and varied but expesnive - I prefer to buy from the pastry shops in the train station, which are excellent. Overall I think the price is a good value.

Well, first of all the beds are really hard. There was no good night sleep and the constant train noise also was carried through from the Shinakawa station near by.The internet connection, was very peculiar. System requires you to rent wifi router from the reception, but of course there was not enough routers available. I was told around 10pm, that I'm the 10th on the queue to possibly have the router. Of course was not able to have it and you can only imagine how difficult it is to attend business meeting next day if you have not been able to see through the latest e-mails... :-(

i suppose this hotel must have thought that four college grads on vacation were out of place among the businessmen who frequent it. we were treated with disdain nearly the entire time. my experience was colored by a combination of a language barrier and substandard service. the following is a horribly detailed account of my point of view.upon arrival, we were first told that we were at the wrong hotel (which we were not; we had a printout for a reservation there). after the receptionist bumbled about for 20 minutes trying to check us in (i have no idea why it took so long), we found that we were being given smoking rooms. because we like to preserve our pulmonary health, we asked for another option. i suppose we should give them points for attempting to accommodate us, but the result was that we were made to switch rooms three times in four nights (one night in a smoking room) because they were fully booked. again, we DID have a reservation. from the staff, no apologies were made and no sympathies were expressed.the whole check in process took about an hour, during which we interacted with the same male receptionist who made several other errors (not noticing the type of beds we had requested in the reservation, for example). as my travel companions and i sat in bored dejection waiting for our check-in to finish correctly, the hotel staff stood around and smiled and bowed and offered to carry luggage--for the suited up businessmen. we were completely ignored.after we were finally checked in, no bellhops offered us any services and we lugged our own stuff up the elevators. not that we minded doing that, but we were also paying customers. why were we not afforded the same respect?as we changed rooms throughout the duration of our stay, the quality of our accommodations declined. on the first night, we had a nice room with two desks and a comfortable sitting area. the pillows were fluffy, the bathroom was clean, the comforter was nice, and there was a spacious entryway. the next room was slightly smaller in both the entryway and the living area, with awkwardly placed furniture that made it hard to move around. the last room change presented hair in the bathroom; a water boiler that made a strange spitting noise; deflated, grainy pillows; a flat, worn, comforter; no entryway section; and an even smaller size than the previous room. we paid the same rate for all rooms.calling the front desk to ask for feminine hygiene products was both embarrassing and frustrating. i attempted to explain my plight to the very confused man who answered the phone and kept mumbling something about "item boat." i kept asking for someone preferably female who spoke english, and it took five more minutes of unproductive back and forth before he finally passed on the phone to a lady who resolved the issue in under 15 seconds. i should mention that i had specifically dialed the "ENGLISH" line to begin with as well.the receptionists we interacted with during our string of checkins and checkouts were not outwardly rude, but they made no effort to be as polite and respectful as they clearly were being to the businessmen. one receptionist looked confused as to why we were switching rooms. the bumbling receptionist who had orchestrated this unfortunate situation for us was standing right next to her, not busy at all. he pretended not to recognize us and left us to explain the situation to her in english. things would have been made much easier had we had a japanese translator, but i guess the available staff was too busy trying to become invisible.there were a few nice staff members, such as the late night receptionist who came outside to translate and helped us chase down a new taxi driver when our first one didn't know haneda airport (how is a taxi driver not familiar with an airport?! but that's a separate issue). the cleaning staff that we encountered greeted us politely.i'd rather spend a little bit more money and get some respect for my business elsewhere. i strongly advise casual travelers to STAY AWAY.

Nice grand hotel - walking distance from JR Shinagawa station with a beautiful Japanese garden. My room had a view of the Tokyo Tower and was able to see Sengakuji temple, where the 47 ronin are buried. English speaking staff were very courteous, friendly and extremely helpful. Service was excellent, as expected from a Prince hotel. Surrounded by other Prince hotels, Grand Prince New Takanawa, Sakura Prince, and Shinagawa Prince.

I found the hotel on internet, and it is 10 m walking from shinagawa station. In summer it is too hot to walk, so i would next time change to prince shinagawa facing the station, and probably cheaper. No gym, and the pool is to the other side of the compound. It is an old stupyle luxury hotel.Reataurant were not great and service so and so. It is frequented for weddings by locals.

The hotel has everything 5 stars hotel can be. The view from the room was amazing, we were looking at the Tokyo tower from our hugh bay window (very impressive and super romantic when it was lit up at night). There are so many prince and pricess hotels, becareful not to book the prince one closest to the train station, as it seems bombarded with group tours.We book the hotel because of the proximity to the shinagawa station, and we had.

I stayed at this hotel right after being at the New takanawa (which no longer had room when I booked) and to be perfectly honest, I liked it better.The room (as seen in the picture) is quite big, and while it could use a refubrish here and there, there was nothing wrong with it or with its cleaness. Probably the best thing was the night view I had from my bed, with the tokyo tower right in the middle proudly lit. During the day you could also see the Skytree far away. To me, this was great, as it was a constant remainder that you are in Tokyo.You should also take into account that, while there was no free wi fi in the room (there is in the lobby), it had a modem cable, so you'll fine as long as you take your notebook.The staff was nice and gentle everytime I asked something (I had my luggage delivered from the New Takanawa), and most of them knew their way around in English.Location wise, It's great. It's only a 5 minute walk to the Shinagawa Station (where some bullet trains stop, like the ones coming from Kyoto), and there are a few restaurants nearby as well, aside from the convinnience store. There was also a Catholic Church one block away.The hotel has a garden that conncets it with the New Takanawa and where many married couples went to have their photos taken ( Everytime I went out, there was a couple).All in all, I highly recommend this hotel, probably even more so htan the New Takanawa, as it was better in pice/quality relation.

The oldest of the four Prince Hotels near Shinagawa station and its starting to show its age. The staff are very helpful, public areas very relaxing and the gardens are beautiful. However, the rooms are very much in need of refurbishment, although spacious and comfortable, they are shabby and lack any real charm. Wi-Fi is not readily available (you have to hire a modem at 1000 Yen) and is sporadic at best. My bathroom (on the 7th floor) was in poor condition with badly stained grouting and a very unpleasant looking waste bin. On the plus side the rates are reasonable (circa 12,000 Yen per night, plus 10% tax) and these seem to reflect the condition of the hotel. In short, this is a lovely old hotel badly in need of some TLC.

We found a deak on the hotel website for ¥4,800 per person per night...which was good for the area around Shinagawa Station.I explained to our kids "Grand" does not mean great, but more like grandparent. The facility is old, but solidly built and well maintained. The age old garden is beautiful...our kids were astounded by the size of colorful Koi carps in the pond. The serenity of this garden us worth the 10-minute walk from Shinagawa Station. 7-11 right outside the property (halfway to the station) makes an economical source of supplies. Hotel staff is very friendly...the bell staff even declined a tip. Wi-Fi is spotty...or maybe I was not supposed to get the signal at all in my room.

Neither a good hotel nor a helpful staff, but a decent deal if you're stuck for late reservations. Good proximity to train station, but a good uphill walk that's tough with a bag. Travel sites advertise a shuttle and free wireless internet, but neither exist. They have wireless Internet in lobby only, painfully slow. This is the least desirable of the prince properties

Not a luxury hotel but good for business purposes. Great location just minutes from Shinagawa station. South side rooms with garden view onto nice Japanese garden. Efficient elevators, not much waiting. WLAN in room at extra cost, wired at zero cost (you can make your own WLAN with tethering). Efficient housekeeping, most of the time they did it while I was at breakfast. One day I had room breakfast, scheduled 6:00 am, which allows them 6:00 – 6:30, arrived 6:15. House guest Sushi menu was very good for the price. Tempura in Wakatake restaurant was rather expensive and had strange things like fried fishbone and small fish to be eaten as a whole, one bitter. So be careful what you choose. Breakfast is fine, except that the table cards they request you to take to the table sometimes are sticky from someone elses jam. A fried egg took very long to make. Had massage late at night, the lady probably was over 70 years old but resolute and she did good work, Anma and Shiatsu, you keep your shirt and pants on, 40 minutes 4.200 Yen. Fresh air lovers can open the window a bit, but then they may get bitten. Four mosquitos even on the 12th floor. One thing annoyed me: They had left a message on the mailbox to tell me that my bill was over 10.000 Yen and I am required to pay “at once”. Firstly, I had given my credit card at check-in, secondly the 10.000 probably should have read 100.000 and thirdly “at once” put me off. I asked them to check again. They probably called after that but that was when I had my massage so I ignored it. Next day I asked the cashier. It obviously had been a mistake. They better check twice before they annoy a guest.

Me and my wife stayed here and found it very quit pleasing, with great views and the garden was outstanding!!! Love the koi fishes, and the proximity to the train station, they even had beer in the vending machines on every floor, the only bad, bad thing for me was the hangovers combined with the jetlag ugh!!! But that was me not the hotel...if I would of known how bad the hangovers are bad in Japan I would have taking it easy on the drinking lol...

I stay frequently at the New Takanawa Prince, but this was my first visit to the Takanawa Prince in about two years. This hotel is usually a little bit less expensive, and depending on your priorities, it may be a better choice.The hotel, lacking the "New" prefix, is indeed somewhat older, probably dating to the 1970s, and this is borne out by details such as the lobby, the in-room furniture, the bathroom fixtures -- and the height of the bathroom counter! But unlike a 40-year-old hotel in North America, Takanawa Prince is impeccably maintained and in very good condition indeed.The rooms are of a decent size by even North American standards, and probably somewhat larger than those in New Takanawa Prince. The furniture aside, they are very clean, with plenty of storage and a well-equipped bathroom. The rooms have either a city view (you should be able to see Tokyo Tower) or a garden view, both are very nice. Beds are firm (as always in Japan) and the pillows are OK.You can choose to skip cleaning on alternate days and get a restaurant/convenience store coupon worth JPY 00 per skipped day. An upside compared to New Takanawa Prince, let alone Shinagawa Prince, is that few large groups seem to stay at Takanawa Prince, so the lobby is much more quiet and calm than at the other two hotels.The walk from Shinagawa Station is a little less than 10 minutes, but it does mean walking up a fairly steep hill. The limo bus from the airport will deliver you to the hotel door, though. The other options for trains are Sengakuji on the Asakusa line (on the same street as the Shinagawa station, but turn left when you get there and walk about 500m) -- or Takanawadai, also on the Asakusa line. Takanawadai is my personal favourite option, and is also less than 10 minutes away, but at the top of the hill. Cutting through the garden and New Takanawa Prince is the fastest way to get there.Shinagawa not only has good connections, it also has a lot of food options. On the west side (where the hotel is), I'll mention the sushi and tempura restaurants in the basement of Wing Tanakawa, Mango Cafe across from McDonald's and Devi Corner near Sengakuji. The east side has scores of restaurants of every type. And Gotanda, with even more choices, including the 82 Ale House, is only about a 20-minute walk away.

This is a fabulous hotel if you only have a few days in Tokyo. Centrally located on the Yamanote train line to see the main attractions of Tokyo, the staff are very friendly and speak English well. Trains and buses are easy to catch to both airports. The rooms are spacious, Internet access available for 1000 yen a day. The garden around the hotel is amazing.
