user_name:
Kate M
Fitzroy Falls, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: Though my stay was for only one night, I found the hotel to be very clean and staff very courteous and helpful. Nice big rooms and excellent breakfast. Free wi-fi in the lobby area. And dont miss the garden in the backyard !!Location is very convenient and not very far from city's attractions.

I chose this hotel because of its proximity to the Shinagawa station (JR company) and Takanawadai (Tokyo subway). We spent 5 days in the hotel and used trains as our transportation to roam around Tokyo. From Narita Airport, it is accessible by NeX trains going to Shinagawa station but we bought the Airport Limousine (bus) ticket coz they will bring you infront of the hotel entrance which costs 6000 Yen round trip plus a free 2 day unlimited rides for Tokyo Metro Line. I had a great time with my family; we are 5 and we got 2 rooms, with different views, the other side on the garden, and on the other side the Tokyo Tower. The room was clean and surprisingly larger, compared to the typical tokyo rooms.Their garden was very beautiful, it has a historical temple on it with a pond filled with fishes, very Japanese themed place, picturesque. We actually bought Yukata and wore it and took pictures in the garden. The garden is known to be a site of cherry blossom trees but too bad we went there mid-spring. There are also a good number of restaurants in the area, a 7-11 convenience store nearby, their cheap packed dinner tastes good actually, a must try. This hotel is uphill and it takes 10 minutes to walk to and from Shinagawa station, but you can use the shortcut by walking through Sakura hotel. The staff are not very good in English but simplifying your words helped them what you meant. It is also a good base for tours, however you need to transfer to the Grand Prince New Takanawa Hotel for pick-ups. The place is quiet coz it is located on a small hill, in a complex of hotels.

A pleasant hotel very close to the train station, hence excellent base for exploring Tokyo. The grounds are gorgeous.All of the staff were helpful and friendly. Fortunately for me, they all spoke Japanese, including the chef who made me a delicious omelette for breakfast.

It was our first trip to Japan and we spent our first 2 nights at Grand Price Hotel Takanawa. Overall, we enjoyed our stay and below are some of the pluses and minuses we experienced.Location is good and easy to find. It's close to Shinagawa Station--about 5 minutes walk but you have to walk up the hill to the hotel (other Prince brand hotels are a little closer and with no uphill walk). I think location makes it a good place for those who are not familiar with Tokyo. Narita Express (certain cars) stops at Shinagawa Station so we were able to travel here directly from the airport without changing trains (saving us from dragging luggages to board crowded commuter trains). Although there are not a lot of attractions nearby, JR Yamanote line stops at Shinagawa Station which makes traveling to Tokyo's major attractions easy. Shinkansen (bullet train) to Osaka, Kyoto, and Nagoya stops at Shinagawa Station, so traveling to and from these cities is easy also.The hotel has a nice garden which is shared with another Prince hotel. When we were there around the end of March, Sakura (cherry blossom) was in full bloom which made the garden very beautiful and a nice place to stroll around and relax.We heard a lot about how small hotel rooms in Japan were but it was a pleasant surprise to see our room was fairly spacious. (It was bigger than other hotel rooms we stayed in during our trip while paying about the same rate). It had a nice garden view. (Rooms on the other side had view of Tokyo Tower). Wire internet was also available from the room and they had wire ready to use in the room.The hotel's AC system can only be set to either cooling or heating at a time for the whole hotel. When we were there, though the weather outside was cold, the room was a bit too warm so we wanted cooling AC system. However, only heat could be used at that time. So if you go there during certain seasons (spring or fall), you might not get what you want as far as AC is concerned.The hotel has a number of restaurants but I couldn't comment on food quality as we didn't dine in any of them. They are much more expensive than restaurants around the station.We also noticed the sign saying that the hotel provided shuttle service to the airport. The price was comparable to Narita Express, so it can be a good alternative if you don't have JR Pass. Again, we didn't use it, so I can't comment on it other than the fact that it's available.Staff were nice and friendly. Check-in and check-out process was quick and easy.Overall, I found Grand Price Hotel Takanawa a good hotel to stay in Tokyo especially for the ease of commute (within Tokyo, to/from the airport, and to/from other cities). It's particularly beautiful and can be a destination by itself in spring when Sakura is blooming!

The Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa is a great hotel within 10 minutes walking distance of Shinagawa Station. It is served by the airport limosine bus which makes it easy to reach from the airport. While the walk maybe considered long by some, it allows you to walk through some very nice scenery which during the Spring season is wonderful. The rooms in the hotel are very large by Japanese standards which enables you to relax during your stay. Depending on the room that you have booked you can see either a view of Tokyo, including the Tokyo Tower & Skytree or a view of the Garden which is very nice indeed. Staff are very friendly in the Hotel and will try their best to speak to guests in English. However, I would advise you learn a little Japanese before you go to Japan as it makes the experience a whole lot more enjoyable. There are several facilities near the hotel including the Aquarium, Cinema and a small eatery plaza. the rooms are clean, in some rooms the walls are slightly thin but it was no bother to us.

This hotel is not that close to the train station. There is another Takanawa Prince hotel which may be confusing for some. Better check before you get there as it can be a bit of a walk with luggage.My biggest complaint is that you find yourself planning your day around the shuttle bus, which really shouldn't be the case on your holiday. You need to catch a shuttle bus to get to the hotel. You have to wait in line for the bus at the train station and when the bus arrives it is just a mad rush for seats as the bus is small. I don't mind walking uphill, but that was just ridiculous. The last bus is also at 8:00pm or 8:30pm. So for some people who think it is a waste of money to spend 710yen (can be spent on sushi instead!) on a cab to take them the short distance uphill or if it is raining too heavily to walk uphill with all your bags, you need to get there is time.Then catching the bus from the hotel requires a reservation. This shuttle also stops at 3 other hotels so be sure to book in advance and not the night before.8pm is far too early to be stopping the shuttle bus, since a lot of shops only shut closer to 10pm. This has been communicated to the hotel but nothing has changed. The room itself is clean. Unfortunately, we requested a non-smoking room but got a room on the smoking floor. The bell captain offered to send up a bottle of air freshener and suggested we open the window to air it out. This helped a bit.There is enough space to have two large luggage open. It is more spacious than a few hotels in Tokyo. There is no WiFi in the room, only in the hotel. The connection is ok but wish a hotel that was charging me that much could provide WiFi in the rooms.The bed is clean and they provide yukatas to use in the room, you will have to search the drawers for them. You can sign up for their 'green cleaning service' which is a decent idea, you get a 500yen coupon for choosing not to have your room cleaned each night.In the middle of the night, there was a man shouting in the next room and the staff failed to handle the situation and he continued to shout throughout the night until early morning ( he got tired?). The air-con was a puzzle, even after putting it on the lowest setting it was still quite stuffy. Since it was raining at the time we couldn't open the window much. Even when the display said 23degs, it felt a lot warmer.Overall, this is a much more expensive hotel which did not deliver. Breakfast was not included, and the hotel is pretty secluded unless you walk back downhill to the station which does have good food. This was a last minute booking for me, if I had the option of early booking, this would not be on my short-list. This is more of a family style hotel or maybe for a wedding. I saw a few weddings held there. The garden was lovely and the koi pond was very serene.

rooms are not renovated since the hotel opened twenty years ago, it seems...sticky carpet, walls full with scratches, supersoft mattress, air con hardly to adjust, worst of all, could hear my neighbours all night long, and they weren't even loud...furthermore, staff is very polite, but hardly understands english. all in all, a miserable stay, was supposed to stay ten days but checked out after the first night. what's on the bright side? well, not much, but the garden and the public spaces are quite nice.

Good place to start visit tokyo. Rooms are functionals and outside there is a nice garden, a real corner of peace in one of the biggest cities in the world! Staff is very kind and helpful, but they don't speak a good english. Breakfast is not included and very expensive, so I walked outside every morning looking for bar or supermarket to get coffee and croissants!

There were another hotel with the same name, but it's called New Grand Prince Takanawa and we went to the wrong hotel. Arrived too late at night and had to drag 4 heavy luggage to get to the hotel in the cold as there were no more free shuttle bus. When we arrive we are requested to go to our hotel which is another 3 mins walk through the garden. Checked in and they gave us a double room instead of twin bed which we have booked. Called the receptionist and says the rooms are fully booked and refuse to give us an upgrade. Very disappointing but we have no choice but to wait for 2 days before they have a twin room for us. Hotel is outdated and room is quite small. Has no wifi in the room and has to go to the lobby to utilize the free wifi connection but it's poor and we hardly get the connections. Free shuttle bus every 30 minutes but advance booking is required. The last bus is at 8.30pm so most likey you'll miss the last bus and has to take a taxi back to the hotel which will costs you around 700yen for the short trip. Else you will need to walk uphill about 10 mins. Overall I'm okay with the stay but will consider going to another hotel instead.

Comfortable and clean room, good size, some small signs of wear. Convenient location if you can stand 5 minutes walk to Shinagawa station. The hotel is on a hill, so the way back could be annoying but they have a bus service from/to the station if you ask. Nice garden and good bars and restaurants. Free wifi in public areas and in the room if you rent a router (1000 JPY)

It's a little far from the JR station, but not too far. You can skip walking up the hill if you enter through the sister hotel. You can take the stairs or elevator through that hotel, and then walk through the central garden. It's quite a nice little stroll, especially if it isn't raining. Shinagawa station, however, has the BEST food of the subway stations we visited. It has great bentos, so be sure to check those out. It also is a central hub, so you can get to Kyoto or Osaka from there.The hotel itself is small but comfortable. Everything was clean and there were no odors in the room. The front desk was fairly helpful, but they didn't speak English very well. They have a money exchange in the lobby, and wired internet in the rooms.All in all, it was a pretty good hotel.

Came back to the Prince hotel complex and have been most impressed with all aspects of the hotel especially the traditional Japanese garden. Additionally the service was first class and room understated, clean and functional. I'd come back again for sure.

We were very happy with this hotel. The location was ideal and easy to get into central Tokyo from. The staff at the hotel were excellent. Our room was fine, clean and not too small. Some of the other reviews had said that the decor was somewhat dated, but it was no problem for us and I'm sure that had it been more up to date in that respect then the hotel would have been much more expensive. As it was, it was good value for money. The setting is xecellent, three connected hotels set around an idyllic Japanese Garden. Very easy to get to and from Narita, take the Airport Limousine bus for the Shinagawa hotels. Cost about 3,000 Yen and takes around an hour and a quarter. Only downside was the coffee, which was so bad we complained and they refunded our money.

On a business trip, in the crazed rush of Tokyo, a hotel sanctuary is a must for some and really good idea for others. The Grand Prince Takanawa Hotel offers a sense of peace and tranquility in the bustle of Toyko. Your inner balance can be restored by resting in their garden or watchng the koi in the pond.A traditional looking build and lobby leads to a more modern, western style room. Service was impressive as two ladies escorted me from the front desk to my room to show me the ammenities. You can even exchange $US for Japanese yen at the front desk. Even if travelling alone, be sure to ask for a room with two beds to get more space.The Grand Prince Takanawa Hotel is conveniently located about a 5 minute uphill walk from the Shinagawa train station. The uphill walk may sound liked a burden but it rewards with good views over the city from rooms higher up.

I have been trying all the hotels around Shinagawa station. There are a lot with almost the same name. The good thing with this hotel is the rooms size. It is getting old but actually very well maintained. The lobby is not a nice experience, like all the other hotels around, but once you are in your room it is a world of silence. My room was a standard one and the size is probably twice what you get in other places. More recent hotels would have newer furnitures but here you have to give space a priority. The garden is lovely and do not hesitate to walk in, especially to go to the next door hotel (forgot the name) which offers international buffet breakfast and is part fo the same group.

The hotel is conveniently located near the Shinagawa Train Station but compared to some other hotels in the vicinity, this hotel requires a further distance and uphill walk. Fortunately, the walk is pleasant if the weather is fine. The hotel is also a stop for the airport shuttle bus even though we found the travel to and from the airport via the train is more convenient. No complaints about this hotel, it's clean and the room size is bigger than some other hotels we have stayed in for 2 people in Japan. Will stay in Shinagawa area again but will try hotels that are closer to the train station.

I last reviewed this hotel in 2009 and gave it 5 stars. Since then I have been a regular visitor, but sadly there has been no investment in the hotel and the rooms have become shabby with dirty carpeting and are now long overdue refurbishment. The location and Japanese garden remain great features, but I have since stayed at the neighbouring Shin Takanawa Prince, which I have found to be better. How disappointing it is to see such a good hotel flounder due to lack of attention.

It was a nice stay, the hotel is very close to the metro line. Also the airport limo is very convenient for the airport travel. The staff were friendly, hotel had good amenities.The room could do with an upgrade else everything was great.

This hotel is in an extremely convenient location, unlike some of the reviews stating that the station is a bit of a walk and you need a shuttle i disagree, it took us just over 5 minutes to walk with our suitcases there, if you have heavy luggage and as it is up a hill get the shuttle but it was fine for us.Station is a JR station so you can exchange Japanese Rail passes here.The room was big for tiny japanese standards and a relatively nice bathroom with a deep bath tub, everything was very clean couldn't complain about that.The restaurants in the hotel were extremely expensive we did not use them, but they do look lovely one being in the lovely zen garden they have outside perfect for summer dining.This hotel does not have a pool but you can share the other Prince hotels pool and gym that is next door but at a cost of of around $15 (Aus).The only real gripe we had was that we arrived at 6.00 in the morning aware that we couldn't check in until 14.00 but at 13.30 they said we could have checked in hours ago as the room was free at a cost and no one had told us.

The hotel is well located, very close to the shinagawa station and since I stayed here just the last night before coming back to Italy, it has been very confortable to find the train narita express leaving directly from such a station and a shuttle service (offered by the hotel) to join it.The lobby and the garden are very nice, quiet, calm and cozy and in the lobby there's also a free wifi service.Rooms are big (according to Japanese standards), a little old style but with a nice view over the city. The bath was also big and clean (the courtesy kit was a little poor).I han no breakfast, nor dinner...so I don't know haw are restaurants.
This hotel is quiet and clean with excellent dinning places and cafe bar.I enjoyed the garden outside of this hotel.Services are good. Clerks were all very friendly and kind.I will be back next time.

We stayed at Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa for 3 nights in June 2012. This hotel is conveniently located for easy access to all parts of Tokyo and the airports since Shinagawa Station is only 8-minute away. Hotel staffs are very professional, friendly and helpful. They provided us with excellent service. We got room #959; it is a superior twin room (two beds) with garden view. This room is spacious and clean. Beds are firm and comfortable; sheets are clean. Bathroom is large and clean. The amenities include: shampoo set, tooth brush set, disposable razor, bathrobe, slippers, shower cap, comb and hair dryer; cotton swabs, ladies' personal care accessories; safe, electric kettle and tea bags, as well as a small fridge. There is free (wired) Internet access in the room and complimentary English newspaper is provided in the morning. Free Wifi is available in the lobby area. Currency exchange service is also available in this hotel. We also got a welcome champagne coupon for two and we used it at Asama Main Bar located on the first floor. There are many restaurants in this hotel and its sisters’ hotels (Prince Hotel Takanawa New and Prince Hotel Sakura). There is also a 7/11 store inside of Prince Hotel Takanawa New. Besides, there is a beautiful Japanese garden in this hotel resort. TIPS for getting to the hotel from the Narita airport:At tourist center in Narita airport, we bought a Suica&NEX package, which costs only 5500JPY (for ordinary car) per package, including round trip JR NEX tickets (Narita to Shinagawa and Shinagawa to Narita), a 1000JPY worth of fare for public transportation within the Tokyo area and 500JPY of refundable deposit. By the way, it costs 3500JPY for a single JR train ticket from Narita to Shinagawa station, so it is already worth the money. Suica can be reloaded at any station; in addition it can be used in some stores and even at the vending machine, very convenient! You can return Suica in the end of you journey (This card becomes invalid if it is not used for ten years) at the ticket counter of a JR (Suica) or non-JR (PASMO) railway station. Unused credit can also be refunded (210 yen handling fee applies).From the Narita airport, it takes about 45 minutes to get Shinagawa Station, which is a big station, very busy, take west exit - TAKANAWA EXIT (WEST EXIT) (see my photo). Here comes tricky part: make sure which Prince hotel you stay with and we learnt it by the hard way. The Prince Hotel Resort including The Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa (old), The Prince Hotel Takanawa New and the Prince Hotel Sakura. There is also a The Prince Hotel nearby, but does not belong to the resort. These hotels are all very close to Shinagawa station. 1. For going to The Prince Hotel Takanawa New, come out from station, cross the pedestrian at green traffic light, turn right and you run into Zakuro-zaka Street in a minute, cross this street first and turn left, then walk up (a small hill, not flat street) about 5-6 minutes and hotel entrance is at your right. 2. For going to both Prince Hotel Sakura and Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa, come out from station, turn right and keep walking until the first traffic light (about 3 minutes, and there is a 7/11 store nearby), cross the pedestrian to arrive at Sakura-zaka Street, walk about 3 minutes to reach Prince Hotel Sakura and 6 minutes to reach Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa. Both are at your left.There is a complimentary hotel shuttle bus goes to Shinagawa Station from all these Prince hotels, but you need to make reservation in advance at hotel and they do not take reservation for pick-up service from Shinagawa Station. However, you can get on the shuttle bus if you run into it at the station.
Modern decor and facilities and excellent service. Well positioned for visiting and attractive setting in gardens.

Stayed at this hotel for 6 nights the first part of July 2012.Found the staff to be very friendly and helpful. In fact I believe they are the jewel of this hotel.Many spoke English very good and most spoke some. The ones who only spoke some were always able to help out with our questions.The hotel has a Japanese garden and koi pond behind the hotel which connects their other hotels.Rooms were fairly spacious compared to what I heard about other Japanese hotels.Bed was a bit hard which took a couple nights to adjust to, but the sheets and comforter were well comfortable. Rooms were quiet.Nice view of the Tokyo tower from our 5th floor room and some of the city.It was raining all week and the hotel sat out umbrellas you could take with you around town. Not sure if that is a custom with all Japanese hotels but this as well as how accommodating they were to the guests is what stands out in my mind about the hotel.They had some restaurants and lounges in the hotel but we only ate at the buffet one breakfast. Compared to U.S. standards a bit pricey and limited menu but more than enough food choice to fill yourself up with.They also had a small business center you could use to make copies, use PCs and print items.If I had the opportunity to return to Tokyo, this hotel is definitely on my list of where to stay.

Have visited with business and pleasure. The staff are alway attentive, helpful and English is normally ok. The rooms are smallish, but clean. Was impressed with first stay so went again with four others. Would recommend. Not right in town, ten min on train but quiet and enjoyable. Love the running around the streets in the area

We had a lovely 5 night stay at the Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa in Shinagawa. We were booked in a "Deluxe Garden View Double King" room and it was enormous, in particular by Tokyo Standards. The room had plenty of room for lounge chairs, a writing desk along with this it had masses of storage space and a large wardrobe and tea making facilities.The hotel is a short walk uphill from Shinagawa station (the walk only took us 5-7 minutes each time depending on whether we took the garden or road path). When you arrive at the hotel you are greeted by friendly staff at the desk along with staff to help with luggage.The hotel is set on a 'complex' with several other Prince hotels with a beautiful garden with carp pond, there are several restaurants on site and at other hotels in the complex. Aside from this there are several convenience stores, a post office (with international ATM) and shops down on the street leading to Shinagawa station. The station itself has many restaurants of good quality if you want to eat near the hotel.The hotel is undergoing renovations and while our room was a little 'dated' I have no doubt it will be on the renovation schedule. It was a very pleasant room to stay in nevertheless.It was nice to stay in a hotel with such a lot of space that was still handy to a large train station with such good service. I highly recommend this hotel and would stay again.

Grand entrance / driveway. Reception staff friendly, polite & welcoming. Was offered a free welcome drink in bar which, disappointingly, you can only take in 1 bar, which is packed full of people smoking (mainly cigars). Consequently, not a nice place to be after a long haul flight. Room was tiny, entrance to bathroom is so small it has to be seen to be believed. Breakfast buffet fine. I did like the free (wired) internet and the fact you can open windows to get fresh air. It's handy for business area & metro, but it's certainly not a luxury or boutique style hotel by any means.

I hated this hotel. Simple enough.So let's try for the positives first. Generously proportioned rooms with largish windows and decent views. Close to the Shinagawa Station on the JR Line of the subway, the best line for connecting to every other line in the wildly complicated if incredibly thorough Tokyo subway system. A decent cafe, the Patio, for light meals and a glass of wine at a reasonable cost. Nice koi pond. Comfortable bus to Narita Airport.Negatives. First the obvious: your reservation will show that you have wifi (surcharge, of course) in your room. Well, not really. In this Japan, once the world's leader in new technologies (remember the Walkman?), in this hotel, you have to ask for a router, which the hotel may or may not have available. If they have one available, they will eventually bring it to your room and plug it in and, voila, you have wifi, which you must renew every day. If they do not have a router available, they you are out of luck, baby! Welcome to the 20th century! Hey, hotel people: install wifi!!! You are a business and convention hotel. Your American business guests were walking around looking for wifi. Wake up Grand Prince, this is the twenty first century, the one where wifi is ubiquitous.Other negatives: let see, the concierge? Useless, worse than useless. Other negatives: I mentioned that the price of wine in the Patio cafe is reasonable. Well, yes, especially compared to the lounge where it is more than twice as expensive, for a glass of wine that is not twice as good; compared to the Bar, where the wine is more than twice as expensive, though not the same price as the lounge, and, again, not twice as good. Compared to the restaurants, where the price is different again, and much more expensive and no better.And more negs: although the location is a 10 minute walk from the Shinagawa Station, it is a 10 minute walk mostly up-hill. There is a van from the hotel to the station every 30 minutes, though when I asked the Bell Captain if there was a van, she said no. For Bell Captain, see the description of the concierge.And more: there are no decent restaurant choices near the hotel. To have an evening out, you must leave, not just the hotel, but also the area, and travel to Roppongi, Omotesando or the Ginza, ok, if you are willing to spring for cabs there and back, or if you have mastered the subway system. The area around the hotel is the most boring in Tokyo.And more: the walls between rooms are paper thin; the ceilings have little or no noise insulation so if the people above you walk with more than a tiptoe, you will hear every foot fall; I had to change rooms, the people above me were so foot heavy. And someone talking in the hall seems to be in your room with you.Btw: do hotels really still use curtains in the shower in the bathroom? I thought that was very last century.More negs: If you can't get a router, you can try the business center (a joke of a name) where access to the internet will cost you Y100 per 5 minutes - of course, there is no help with the system, which is in Japanese, so your first couple of hundred yen are used trying to figure out how to connect, and how much e-mail can you handle in one five minute increment? My advice - go to the concierge, who is useless, and demand that she find you a router for your room, and that she do that immediately. Stand your ground in front of her desk, and continue to make your demand; magically, a router, heretofore unfindable, will appear in your room. Golly!I would never choose this hotel again, nor recommend it to anyone. It's not that it sucks, it's that it does nothing well, and does many things so poorly as to be almost laughable; laughable that is, unless you really need wifi, and then it isn't laughable, it is unforgivable.Ophelia, get thee to another hotel in a better part of town!

William B
New York City, New York

review_body: Look beyond the fact that this hotel is a little dated in decor and its a great, affordable option in a very expensive city. Positioned right next door to Shinagawa Train Station, this is the perfect place to reach most areas of Central Tokyo. It is also within easy reach of Haneda Airport, by both Door to Door Limosine Bus (very cheap), or on the train link. The development is made up of a number of hotels, all surrounding a beautiful Japanese Garden - the perfect place to escape the city, for a bit of peace, quiet (and culture). Essentially the hotels are all aimed at the group and meetings market - but perfect also for individual travellers. The rooms are spacious with good facilities. My only complaint is that the internet connection is not WiFi (but it is complimentary, albeit a wired connection). Breakfast is extensive and adequate - with both Japanese and Western options. The service is first class throughout - attentive and very friendly. This is a great option for both business and leisure travellers.

I spent a week at the Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa in the beginning of May and was very pleased with my stay. The room was tiny, miniscule to be exact, but it was very clean and comfortable and I really didn't spend a lot of time sitting around. The bathroom was also small, but the water was always piping hot which was great. The hotel staff were very helpful, arranging several sight seeing trips and my airport drop off which was a 2:00 a.m.!!!! I had dinner in the Steak house which adjoins the hotel and it was shockingly expensive, but absolutely marvelous! Kobie beef cooked right at my table so that I felt like royalty and it was worth every penny. I also had dinner in the French restaurant and that was fabulous as well! The hotel grounds are simply stunning and it was delightful to sit by the pool that was filled with Koi and read. The hotel is located up the hill from the very convenient Shinagawa station and the stores and restaurants by the station were also well stocked and interesting. I loved Japan and plan to visit again and would stay at the hotel as well.

I've stayed at this hotel numerous times while on business in Tokyo. The rooms may not be the most modern, by Marriott or Hilton standards, but they are clean and quite nice. The are on the small side, as this is Japan after all. The Grand Prince Takanawa is a very traditional Japanese hotel. The service is extremely good, the restaurants are very good and the Japanese garden in the rear of the hotel is the nicest feature of this beautiful property. I have come to enjoy very peaceful morning walks in the spacious garden before business starts for the day. This kind of sanctuary in the heart of Tokyo is incredibly unusual and a real treat. If you like older (probably built in the 60s), more traditional hotels you won't be disappointed. If you're a chain/points guy that prefers upscale US hotels like Hyatt, Westin, Hilton, Marriott then this probably isn't for you. I'm an American businessman who likes to stay at and eat the local fare when traveling in Japan.

Most hotel rooms in tokyo are usually small by international standards. This hotel, though located a bit further from the main road and Shinagawa station, has spacious rooms and quiet location. Staff are genuinely helpful and speaks excellent english, useful for non japanese speaking tourists/businessmen. Several restaurants with the steak house (opened since 1969) and located in a quaint buiilding beside the hotel complex looks promising although it was under minor renovation and we did not have enough time to try it as well.

Situated in Shinagawa, a short train ride from Shibuya, Shinjuku and many other interesting places in Tokyo, we stayed here for three nights in May 2012. Ask for a room overlooking the gardens. The room was comfortable and clean although the bathroom is quite small. Breakfast at the Patio in the hotel was great, with a mix of western and Japanese offerings - try the Japanese breakfast items - they're great. The hotel staff are very helpful and there's a frequent courtesy bus to Shinagawa station. If you like walking, the station is only about 10 minutes away on foot. Would gladly stay here again.

We stayed here in January 2012 for four nights.The rooms were very large, particularly for Japan and overlooked the beautiful Japanese gardens. This area of the complex is so quiet for a central Tokyo hotel, and yet the Shinagawa Station is only a five minute walk away.While the rooms were not luxurious, they were furnished quite stylishly.It was bonus having a full size desk to put the laptop,newspapers, maps etc., on.We will stay here again and would suggest the Delux Garden Rooms for that little bit extra comfort.A great value hotel!

We stayed two nights. Hotel has very good location five minutes walk to Shinagawa Station.Price is good compare to other hotels in Tokyo and also the room is bigger than Japannesse standard. If you are in Japan in between March and April you can enjoy Sakura trees in the hotel garden. Although staff is very helpfull there is not enough English in the room so it is better to ask how to use remote control in the front desk. No free internet connection.

The Grand Prince Takanawa is part of a complex of Prince hotels near Shinagawa Station. This means that is is very convenient for taking bullet trains, subways, the the Japan Rail train that loops around Tokyo. There is a beautiful garden between the hotels. The rooms are large for a moderate-priced hotel and have every possible amenity. The staff is very helpful and knowledgeable. We were in Tokyo for a family wedding and the whole family stayed at the hotel and all agreed that is was a good choice.

We stayed twice, once at the start of our holiday and once at the end. After a very early arrival at Shinagawa station and not realising how close the hotel was we jumped into a taxi who took us to the wrong hotel. Soon sorted out, we dropped off our luggage and returned later to our garden view room. Plenty of space, good sized bathroom, comfortable beds.Two negatives, no English speaking channel on tv and my big moan wifi only available on payment of 1000 Yen, in this day and age I think it should be available for free as it was in some of the less expensive hotels we stayed in.Ok I've got that off my chest. Shinagawa station a simple journey from Hadena airport, convenient for JR Yamamote line and Shinkansen is less than a 10 minute walk away. There is a shuttle bus which departs from the front of the station ever half hour or so at 2 and 32 minutes past the hour.Reception staff all seem to be English speakers.The garden area is very attractive and good for a stroll day or night.Tokyo has a wide choice of hotels but for us this struck a good balance of cost and comfort.

This hotel shares its wonderful garden with its sister hotel the Hotel New Takanawa. The rooms are slightly larger than usual for Tokyo, but the bed is very hard by western standards, and the chairs are uncomfortable. Then rooms are clean and otherwise OK. Staff is friendly and helpful, and the hotel has better than average restaurants. The hotel also has a periodic free shuttle to Shinagawa Station, that is excellent.

Expedia photo is of a upgraded room but the lower cost booking is for a basic older room. At the hotel we upgraded to a more modern room. Cost of upgrade was moderate. Modern, spacious and comfortable on the 9th flr. with terrific views over Tokyo. Staff were very helpful (as they are in all Japanese hotels I've stayed in) and there is a convenient convenience store on the ground flr. A short uphill walk from the station and a shuttle bus is also available. It was Winter and snowing so we caught a taxi for about AUD$8.00.

I moved from the East Tower of the Prince Hotel where I stayed for work to this hotel on Feb 9th and what a surprise! The first things I noticed was the sense of space and tranquility. The foyer is very large and spacious and there are staff everywhere to make sure that you are OK. Check-in is also friendly and swift and you are provided with a lot of information about the many features of this hotel.When I went to my room I could not believe how large it was and everything else about it. My room overlooked an aspect of the city of Tokyo including Tokyo Tower - it was fabulous. The bathroom was also large and was well equiped with everything you could want. There is free internet and a range of local and cabel TV stations.This hotel offers a number of restaurants, a nice wine bar, a true cigar bar and a lovely tea/coffee lounge that has huge glass windows overlooking a very impressive Japanese garden and mini lake. I liked the tempura restaurant the best but there is so much to choose from at this hotel. The small lake is filled with beautiful coloured fish and the garden also has a tradition Japanese Tea House which is open for some parts of the day. The gardens are tranquil and so beautifully and it is great to be able to walk around outside a hotel. As others have mentioned the hotel is on top of a hill but the regular free shuttle service does not make this a problem also, the walk down to Shinagawa area or station is not difficult. A friend of mine recommended this hotel and I am very happy I took his advice and stayed here! I would return any time I am in Tokyo!!

Located on top of a hill with regular half hour shuttle service from Shinagawa station - check the schedules posted on the pillar next to the taxi stand. The Prince group of hotels are situated next to each other and share facilities including a swimming pool, a beautiful Japanese garden and the like. Service was very polite and the staff were quick to locate someone who spoke English in case of communication difficulties.Free internet with very quick back-up service as I had a problem with the LAN cable. A plethora of restaurants in the area - not only in the hotels but also within and surrounding the Shinagawa station. A cluster of ramen shops around the south entrance is very popular and inexpensive. The Wings Department store in the station has a nice food section in the basement and there is also another grocery store near the taxi stand with all sort of imported foodstuff. Overall, I would return to stay.

We were delighted, having moved from Keio Plaza after two nights (because they were full) to Grand Prince Takanawa with a garden view deluxe room. The room overlooked the Japanese garden, giving a very calm and relaxing feel with the Koi Pond just below. We watched the welcoming of the New Year celebration right from our room! From the lift lobby, you can see the Tokyo Tower looming right in front! The staff were very helpful. The hotel is right near to Shinagawa JR Station within walking distance or take the hotel shuttle. We walked as it was perfectly good weather and we do need the extra exercise. Overall, we enjoyed our stay with numerous restaurants to choose from both on property as well as within the other Prince hotels surrounding the garden.

I moved to this hotel for three nights, at a very last-minute notice after running into some unpleasant experiences at the Shinjuku Prince Hotel. The reservation was made hurriedly by my business associate, but the hotel staff were more than ready to receive me when I arrived to check in that evening.This hotel is located at the top of a hill, and it is not easy to locate the shuttle bus if you do not know where it stops. I was unable to find the shuttle bus stop at the Shinagawa Station, so I trudged my way uphill with my luggage and belongings. If you are anything short of being very fit, this can be a very tiring task.Service at this hotel was very good. The Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa actually shares its immediate area with two other hotels in the Prince group of hotels, namely the New Takanawa and Sakura Tower. It can be confusing to figure out which entrance was which if you have never been here, and I ended up at the New Takanawa instead. However, the hotel staff were very nice, and even had a bellhop help me with my luggage and direct me to the correct hotel. These three hotels share a common, but very large Japanese garden, which is a must-see if you stay here.My room at this hotel was large with a high ceiling, and included two twin beds, a large sofa and desk. The room was very clean, and the bathroom was spotless. A slated wooden door separated the main entrance/closet/bathroom area from the rest of the room, which gave it an almost suite-like feel. The furnishings were rather old and dated, but I appreciated the space that this room offered, a rare treat when it comes to Tokyo hotels.During my first two nights here I ran into some problems with the free Internet connection, and was unable to log on to do my work. However, the toll-free tech support was very helpful, and spoke excellent English. I was eventually able to solve my problem.This hotel is great in all aspects - large spacious room, clean and safe premises, attentive service. This is not a luxury stay, but if you are looking for a nice, comfortable, resort-like place to stay, then this hotel is an excellent choice.

There is a half hourly shuttle bus from hotel to train station that makes this Hotel a good locationfor its price. For those who wish to swim, the same shuttle takes guests 3min away to Shinagawa Prince hotel which is on the main road.

We stayed in the Shin Takanawa Prince. There are two other hotels in this complex, Takanawa Prince and Sakura Tower, which are operated separately, each with its own registration desk.We travel light and walked to the hotel entrance. It was a longish 10-minute trip up a slight grade.As is common in Japan, staff was always very friendly and helpful. Since we arrived before check-in time, we just dropped off our bags. When we came back later, our room had been assigned and our bags had already been delivered.Our room on the tenth floor was spacious, with a large king size bed, sofa and desk. Much larger than we had expected for the rate paid.From our balcony, we could see Tokyo Tower, brightly lit up in the evening sky. For our night activities we went out the back way, through the garden next to the Takanawa Prince and then into and out of the Sakura Tower. This route also leads to the Shinagawa station. The garden was decorated for Christmas but most of the lights were in the shape of Santa Claus in various sizes. In each lobby, however, we found delightful Christmas trees and other decorations.We would certainly stay here again should the opportunity arise.
This is very nice and modern hotels. It has large room and bathroom. Japanese hospitality is commendable. Good choice of breakfast and god restaurant in the vicinity. Overall satisfying experience.

A fantastic hotel, loved it! The rooms were spacious for a Tokyo hotel (Garden View rooms recommended), and the ambiance, helped much by the gardens, was subdued and peaceful. Breakfast was excellent quality, though a tad on the expensive side. Staff were friendly and helpful.

We would recommend a city room view, and breakfast is very good, but only OK at Y 2500. The Narita Express from the airport is great but beware the train splits into two at Tokyo so ensure you are in the right carriage and train for Singawa. The Suica plus nexcard is highly recommended. The gardens of the hotel are very good and if you are lucky there are weddings taking place. If you have heavy luggage it is probably best to get the limousine bus from the airport, but we had luggage and preferred arriving by train with a short steep walk to the hotel from the train station, without luggage there is a short cut through the hotel garden grounds up a flight of steps.

Hotel is a short walk uphill from Shinagawa Station, which is a Shinkansen stop and thus a very convenient area to stay if you're planning on using it (the area around the station itself is not exciting). We chose the hotel as we were arriving late at night in Tokyo and knew that it was a stop for the limousine bus from Narita - that alone is a great reason to stay there.Service is exceptional and check in/out were a breeze. The rooms where we stayed (at the beginning and then at the end of our trip) are not very updated but are spotless clean and there are plenty of amenities. We thought they were quite spacious. Free internet is a great plus.Overall, very satisfied with the hotel and would definitely go back.

Having been away from Japan for some time and coming back - this is a great place to stay for our return.As soon as we got off the shuttle bus, a helpful female member of staff was ready with a trolley for our luggage and was able to recommend some good restaurants, direct us to the right places, was friendly and talkative. I noticed the staff were wearing Aloha-Hawaii style shirts which matched their character and helpfulness. I guess if you've spent some time in Hawaii, you'll find that spirit here. Being situated on the hill, it was super peaceful with a good view of the Tokyo Tower. The rooms have the essential home comforts, are clean and inviting. For the best ramen - try the Chinese Restaurant located in the Annexe.

Excellent Hotel in a good Tokyo district for visitors. Within walking distance (10 minutes), right up the hill from the busy Shinagawa station, this hotel is a great choice from which to access the city. Front desk service is polite and professional, most importantly proficient in English, including a currency desk for obtaining the all important yen. Rooms were spacious and comfortable for Japanese standards.

After a long haul flight from SFO, I stayed at Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa.As I checked in almost midnight, I was upgraded to a superior room. The room seems to have been renovated, very clean,spacious bathroom with full of amenities(Toothbrash, Razor, Bath salt, Shampooand Conditioner, Shower gel, Hair brush, Cotton buds and Hair cap, ) also free wi-fi !There is a free shuttle bus between Shinagawa Stn. but it just takes 7-10min. on foot. Shops and restaurants around Shinagawa Stn. opentill late, even Mcdonald's. Superior rooms have balconies, overlooking either Tokyo tower side or Japanese garden situated in the proparty. Very quiet roomnever annoyed from any noise. Overall, I would recommend this hotel on your stay in Tokyo.

The Prince hotel chain runs a huge complex of interrelated hotels on the west side of the Shinagawa station (a major shinkansen stop on the south side of Tokyo), and the Grand Prince Takanawa was one of the first to open. Of course there is the usual extraordinary staff attention at the front desk that one finds in top-flight hotels all over Japan. The rooms are adequate in size, but by our standards they do economize on space. Free Internet access is a plus, and I have no complaints.Because the nuclear power plant disaster in Fukushima has robbed Tokyo of one of its main sources of electrical power, the hotel--and the city--are subject to heavy pressures to reduce electrical waste on luxuries like air conditioning. This was translated by the hotel into a restriction barring guests from setting the room thermostat below 28⁄° C (82° F). Given Tokyo's normal summer weather--hot and muggy--this meant that sleeping was not entirely comfortable. There is a tastefully laid out "Japanese garden" connecting this hotel with its "New" counterpart, and it includes a reassembled centuries-old tea house. Across the street from the New hotel entrance, for those interested in such things, is one of Tokyo's few Catholic churches; and of course it is a 5-minute walk from the Shinagawa train station.

After a trip to Hakone, I stayed over at Takanawa for 2 days. As indicated, it met all of my expectations. From arrival, they were polite and spoke reasonably good English (something I felt comfortable).My luggage was transferred from another hotel and they quickly made arrangements to transfer it to my room. I stayed a high floor room, with a fantastic view of Tokyo Tower and the city. For the price I paid, I considered it one of the best hotels to stay in. Rooms are of decent size and facilities are plenty. Location to Shinagawa station is reasonable distance and there are shuttle buses if you are coming from the airport.

This hotel was only a short walking distance from Shinigawa Train Station.Although its situated in a bustling business part of Tokyo, it felt secluded with its garden surroundings and a part view of Mt Fuji (on a clear day). The room was a little bit dated, but large enough for a short or long stay. To be honest, our room was pricey for what it was, but we were lucky enough to pay special rates which made it worthwhile.We had previously stayed in another part of Tokyo on our first part of the trip so we felt Shinigawa was a bit quieter with limited opportunities for dining and leisure.

We had a great stay and would definitely return.The hotel and very clean, modern and efficiently run. The staff are excellent and very helpful. The rooms very fine, small by US/AUS standard but reasonable to big by Japanese standard. They were modern and clean.There is an ATM with VISA in the adjacent company hotel.Free internet via LAN cable in the room.The areas is safe at night, and has plenty of eating options. It is very handy for transport, as Shinagawa is on the JR Yamanote line. In addition, there are trains (with no changes) from Narita, Haneda, plus the bullet train (towards Nagoya, Kyoto and Osaka).

This is an enormous hotel complex, with comfortable rooms and spectacular gardens.IT seems to cater to a lot of large groups, but that does not detract from the pleasantness of the hotel (usually I avoid these sorts of large group hotels). The breakfast was wonderful--a buffet with Asian and Western breakfast options and terrific service.My 8 year old adored the koi pond and wandering in the garden, which was especially beautiful as the autumn leaves were changing. She was ill while we stayed there and the hotel staff was wonderful--they brought up a thermometer and offered to get us to a hospital. For such an enormous hotel, we were surprised at the level of attentiveness.

my family (with 2 teenagers) stayed for 9 nights/10 days in this hotel..It was perfect in every sense of a leisure stay. I booked this hotel through hotel.com and upon arrival was upgraded to a suit overlooking the tokyo tower. The room we stayed was spacious and comfortable..the room amenities were over flowing... Replenishments were given every day. they never skimp in what we needed may it be for more coffee bags,sugar,cream etc..the hotel housekeeping was efficient and personalized. the concierge though very busy was helpful.Over all the staff was very respectful (typical of a Japanese culture) There are 3 big Prince hotel in the area, separating them is a beautiful Japanese garden..a shuttle bus takes you to the main train station. "shinigawa" . The hotel provides tours and airport services with a fee.My family was very satisfied with this hotel...my standards now are very high in choosing hotels because of this experience.

Dissapointing stay. Room was dingy and old. Carpet stained. Place was just worn out. It must have been awesome back in the 60's or 70's! The bar was open late and was pretty cool if not a bit dark and old school which had it's charm. The breakfast restaurant (Patio) was ok. Food quality was acceptable. I asked the chef to make me an egg white omlet and he did which was nice as they had an omlet station with a vat of premixed egg and could have easily told me that that was what he had. Great garden to walk around in at night and during the day. I had a nice view of it and opened the window for some fresh air. The hotel charged for everything. Check out time was 10am with 1000 yen for each additional hour. Why? 2100 yen for the Fitness Center, 500 yen for the Sauna. The Fitness Center and Sauna were great, in fact down right exceptional, and I paid for them but what the heck? The fitness center was clean, very well equipped. It was the best I saw in all of Japan on this trip.

Having spent this last year travelling several times to Tokyo to liaise with my Japanese girlfriend, I have stayed at a few hotels, in the budget (well budget in a Japanese sense) sector of accomodation, around the $100-$120 night range... the overwhelming picture I gained from this was 'Space is Precious', i.e. most rooms are very, very compact to say the least. The Grand Prince Takanawa was a blessing as the room was actually quite spacious for Japanese standards and the price we got was in the same region as what I had paid for the broom closets I stayed in previously. The staff were very polite and helpful, our first night had us staying in a room which reaked of old cigarette smoke (not uncommon in Japan), a request to be moved to another room was done with lightning speed and efficiency, actually moved us up 4 more floors for a very spectacular view. A request for a wine bottle opener and 2 plates to our room had a complete tray of plates, cutlery, wine glasses, cloth napkins and an ice bucket full of ice! Overall a very pleasing stay, would highly recommend this hotel

Highly recommended, of all the four star this is the best, better than the lower ranked 5 star hotels. Although the room did not have good city view it made up for it in other areas.Can stay here again.

This hotel is not located in the heart of tokyo nor is it close to the main shopping area or the clubbing area but its a phenomenal property spread over quite a large area with a convention centre attached to it too. I stayed on the cliub floor. The rooms are quite big unlike other hotels in the heart of tokyo and feature a large screen flat panel, a DVD player and so on. Beds are quite comfortable and definitely very inviting after a long day. the bathrooms are well equipped and wont leave you wanting for anything. the hotel also has a very verdant garden along with a gushing stream developed around it which makes for a very different and a very soothing environment Definitely a grat hotel to stay in.to travel around, the local train station is only a short walk away too !

We stayed 3 nights there and it was a good choice. Not too far from the metro, close to the "Eiffel Tower", also supposedly near the train station, but I did not check that!Our room was fairly large and with a nice view of the Tower. Clean, sterile, and in need of paint. Not much charm, but that's ok. Need a good decorator. The restaurant on the 10th floor was quite good for breakfast and dinner (though expensive).In general, the service was quite good except for one snobbish woman who "greeted" us.

From the moment our airport limousine pulled up to the moment we left, the service was impeccable. The number of people available to help guests seemed to have been carefully calculated, so that we never had to wait for than a couple of minutes, even during the busiest times of the day. Just as we were leaving for the train station to catch our train for Kyoto, we noticed that there was a free shuttle but that we had just missed one. So, we headed to the station on foot. Before we got 20 feet from the hotel, a car drove up, and the driver offered us a ride. He refused our tip, insisting that it was part of the hotel's basic services.We also loved the setting of the hotel. Beautiful pond and garden behind the hotel--hard to believe that we were minutes away from midtown Tokyo given the serenity. The hotel is also close to two metro / JR station stops, which made it very convenient for us. Kudos also for the excellent size of the rooms, especially in comparison with the typical Japanese rooms.

just returned fromTokyo. Have stayed in Shinjuku and Ebisu areas for work many times before. This was a personal trip to attend the Tokyo Anime Fair with my teenager. This is a great hotel. Just a short walk to the hotel from JR Shinagawa station (it is an uphill walk, so there is a frequent shuttle if you don't want to walk or have luggage). The grounds are beautiful. is a link to a video of the gardenswww.youtube.com/user/endersgame99?feature=mhw5#p/a/u/0/_Rtfia5aM9s Food in the hotel of course is pricey, but at and around the station, there are many restaurants. and if you must, there is a Starbucks and a McDs there also...i had to have my morning latte. Everyone speaks English well and service was great. Location great to jump on JR lines and get anywhere.

Summary: Great price (Expedia); "large-ish" (by Japan standards) room & bath; expensive restaurants; business-oriented; convenient 5-10 minute walk to Shinagawa Station, 7-11, McDonald's, grocery & bentos; quiet area -- not a glitzy tourist-oriented location; Sakura on hotel grounds; friendly staff; on a small hill; limo-bus from Narita.Our family (2 college age, 2 teenage) spent last week at this hotel and thoroughly enjoyed it. The hotel appears to be domestic (Japan) business oriented, but there were tourists there as well (some Chinese and Europeans). The neighborhood is not in a bustling touristy space; it's a quiet area which was nice to escape some of the insanity of the city. Slight uphill walk from the west entry ("Takanawa Entrance") of the Shinagawa Station to the hotel (old fogies might not like it). There is a convenient ATM across the hotel garden just inside of the back entry to the neighboring GP New Takanawa hotel (also a small drug store and convenience store there, too). We caught the "Airport Limousine Bus" from Narita (slightly cheaper than via train and much more convenient w/ drop-off & pick-up at the front door of the hotel). The hotel grounds are beautiful (lots of Sakura) so the locals have weddings there.We would usually head out in the mornings from our room at the GP Takanawa, cross the garden to the GP New Takanawa, visit the ATM for the day's shopping/eating expedition, then cross the main lobby of the GP New Taka., drop down one floor at the large stair well at the faaar end of the lobby, and exit out past the pastry shop onto the street. Via that street, it's a down hill stroll (less steep than the winding road between Shinagawa Station and the main entry to the GP Takanawa) east to the short driveway (it's on your right, just after the Royal Host diner) to the Epson Aqua Stadium (dolphin show and penguins if you're interested). Once at the entry to the Epson, head left down hill into the building complex and you'll walk right past the 7-11 (to pick up misc. supplies or snacks). Keep walking down the stairs, and you'll find the McD's for a convenient bite (note that McD's has hot dogs in Japan!). You'll also be at the cross walk to Shinagawa Station. After you cross the street from McD's and just enter the station complex, there's an escalator to your right that heads down a flight into a store with tons of bento boxes (take-out Japanese food) as well as a groceries in the back (note that the bentos and the groceries are separate vendors). We would usually visit this place at the end of our day to pick-up great tasting, cheap eat-in food, snacks and drinks if we were tired and just wanted to kick-back in the hotel room. Note that the hotel room trash cans are tiny, so save those plastic grocery bags for your trash -- the hotel housekeepers will appreciate your neatness.The station has lots of food places in the JR Lines main concourse, through the central ticket gate (just inside of the west (Takanawa) entrance). Note that these are on the platform side of the turnstiles, so you have to either purchase a train ticket or have a rail pass on hand to get in there. If, for some reason, you fear turnstiles, there's also a big Starbucks towards the east entry to the station, up on the 2nd floor, that has a terrific view of the mass of humanity marching through the station (snag a table overlooking the main lobby before ordering your beverage and croissant).I'd do it again.

This hotel is perfect if you are traveling to Japan for the first time. Our room had a great view of the city and at night could see the Tokyo Tower. The room was a good size and very clean. Since we haven't been to Japan before we were a little worried about finding our way around. Luckily, our hotel was just 10 walking minutes away to the fabulous Shinagawa Station. The Shinagawa Station was extremely convienient since it connects to may train lines. Also in walking distance was 7-11 for those late night snacks or a quick breakfast before jumping on the train.We ended up staying there our entire trip, 9 days and truly enjoyed the experience.

Me and a couple friends (all young adults) stayed at this hotel for a summer vacation. The hotel its self is very clean, upscale and nice. Its located in a business area, so the hotel is aimed for the business crowd, though we didn't have any problem enjoying it. Our rooms were comfortable and we even had a great view of the garden and koi pond from our room. The hotel's garden connects it to two other hotels located in the area. Because the hotel was aimed to the business crowd they did have a small business room with free internet service, which was nice. However, internet in you room cost money. The hotel also had about 4 or 5 restaurants located inside for you to eat.The hotel is located in the Sinagawa area, which is not a popular tourist area but a popular business area. We didn't find this a problem, because the hotel was located close to the train station where you can take the Yamamoto line to all of the major tourist areas of Tokyo (Harajuku, Ginza, Shibuya, ect). Each area is about 15-20 mins away on the train, but beware the train stations close at 2am! Every day we would wake up, walk down the street, get breakfast at the McDonalds near by then jump on the train to explore. I would recommend staying in this area because even though it was father away from the city, all attractions are reachable by train. We got to see all of Tokyo with out paying lots of money for a hotel located in the heart of Ginza or Shibuya.

I stayed here with 3 friends for 5 nights while in Tokyo. The location is really nice, just a block from the Shinagawa Station, which is one of the busiest stations, but you have to walk up a small hill to find the hotel. Since you're by the station, there's a good number of restaurants, even a McDonald's, which was the cheapest thing to eat in Tokyo. There isn't much sightseeing around Shinagawa, but the station connects to the main JR Rail Line in Tokyo, so you can reach more exciting places within 15 minutes. The hotel is a very nice business-type hotel. Contrary to the exterior of the hotel, the decor in the lobby and rooms is actually new and nice, plus its very clean. We picked the hotel because it was cheaper, so I was expecting it to be worse, but the rooms were very nice and much like typical American hotels, in size and cleanliness. We felt a little out of place because there didn't seem to be any other tourists in the hotel, but the staff was always extremely polite and helpful. The hotel is actually part of 3 hotels that share grounds, which include a large Japanese-style garden. Also, many tours pick-up from one of the New Takanawa, which is convenient. Overall, it was a really good base location to explore Tokyo. It was surprisingly very clean and nice on the inside, and I felt for the price it was a really good value.

We just returned from Tokyo - our stay at the Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa was great. The hotel is in an excellent location within walking distance from the Shinagawa Train Station. You can take the train from the airport right to Shinagawa or another station that is on another line. If you travel outside of Tokyo on the Shinkansen (bullet train) you can walk to the station for the Shinkansen. The GP Takanawa is part of a complex with three or four other GP hotels that share a beautiful Japanese garden. Within walking distance there are sights to see, restaurants, shops and most important plenty of transportation. If you travel to Tokyo, be prepared to walk. There is a slight incline on the street that goes from the Shinagwa Station to the hotel, but it is not bad. We used to save a little of distance by entering through the nearest hotel and cutting through the lobby to the garden. My only complain about the stay was that TV was all in Japanese... but then again you are not going to Japan to watch TV, so that is a minimal inconvinience. Eating in the hotel can be expensive, so I suggest you look outside. Breakfast buffet runs $25/person, but it is a brunch that includes from soup to nuts... literally. So you can have breakfast and dinner and you will be fine.In conclusion, we would stay again in that hotel when we go back to Tokyo.

A bit of a walk up the hill to the hotel from the Shingawa Station - 10mins. Staff all very nice and helpful. English is pretty good. Rooms small but comfortable, bathrooms just ok - kids amazed by the toilets which were heated and run water to disguse any sounds when you sit down. No connecting rooms but kids in a room straight across the hall which works out ok. All single beds no double/queen etc but this seems the norm all over Japan. Breakfast is good. Would stay here again.

Spent 3 nights in this beautiful hotel, very well located near to the Shinagawa station. I was able to make the reservation directly in their website for a very affordable rate, and as in the old days, pay at check out time. Staff is very polite. The hoteI has a beautiful Japanese garden, which makes the location even better. Many cheap places to eat around the hotel. A few minutes walk from the Yamanote train line, although it is as close to the Tokyo subway as well. Very clean rooms with all the nicknacks that Japanese are so well known for. I would recommend this hotel to anyone who is visiting Tokyo.

The Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa is a beautiful hotel with rooms that are state of the art! From heated toilet seats, heated bathroom mirrors and very comfortable beds this was a really wonderful place to stay. The ONLY negative is that the restaurants (4 to choose from) were not exactly kid friendly. But there are places close to the hotel (walking distance) that are. Great shopping near by, easy access walking and shuttle to the train stations, this is a real GEM! I would most certainly return to the Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa - it is a hotel fit for a KING!
